chunks.original_text: 此言水轻而浮，为后天之气，属外药； 金沉而重，为先天之命，号真铅——又号金丹，又号白虎初弦之气，其名不一，是为内药。 先天金生水，为顺行之常道，生人以之，故曰重为轻根。 夫人生于后天，纯是狂荡轻浮之气作事，以故水气轻而浮，情欲多生，命宝丧失，所以易老而衰。 君子有逆修之法，无非水复生金，轻返于重，以复乎天元一气。 是以终日行之，而不离乎辎重。 不过亭亭矗矗，屹然特立，厚重不迁，养成浩气，充塞乾坤而已矣。 此为逆修之仙道，炼丹以之。 总之由有形以复无形，丹道之一事也。 火燥而动，为后天之神，属外药； 木静而凝，为先天之元性，曰真汞，曰真精，又曰青龙、真一之气，其名亦多，要皆内药。 先天木生火，为顺行之常道，生人以之，故曰“静为躁君”。 夫人成形而后，纯是智虑杂妄之神用事，以故火性飞扬，变诈百出，性真梏没，所以易弱而倾。 君子有倒施之功，无非火复生木，躁返于静，以还乎不二元神。 于此虽有荣观，燕处超然，无非万象咸空，一真在抱，养成大觉真金仙，召回霄汉而已矣。 此为逆炼之丹道，成仙以之。 要之自有觉以还无觉，又修道之一端也。 此由外药以修内药，自后天而返先天也。 吾更为之畅言曰：生人之道顺而生，修仙之道逆而克，盖不克则不生，亦不克则不能成。 河图洛书之所以生克并用也。 今之儒释修养，与吾道有异者，大抵彼用顺行，一循自然之度； 吾道独逆炼，则有勉强作为之工。 倘有不克，无以为生成也。 但顺而修则易，逆而修则难。 不得真师，不明正法，妄采妄炼，鲜不为害。 既得真师，明正法矣，不结仙缘，不修善功，则神天不佑，魔魅来缠，必有将成而败，倾丹倒鼎，连身命俱丧者，此诚不可不慎也。 何以逆之克之？ 始用顺道之常，效夫妻交媾之法，以火入水乡，即是以神入气中，此为凡父凡母交而产药。 迨至火蒸水沸，水底金生，斯时玄窍开而真信至，是真阳生而子药产，此为外药。 金气既生，真铅自足，予以火促水腾，木载金升，切切催之，款款运之，上升乾鼎，以真铅配真汞，以真火真意引之，下入丹田，即入坤腹，以炉鼎和药物炼丹，此返坎为男，复离为女。 颠倒女男，选为宾主，收归炉内，烹炼一晌，再候真阳火动，以为金火大药。 此为内药生，又曰大药产。 此为灵父圣母交媾而育者也。 且前小药之生，动在肾管外，其气小，故曰小药、外药； 此则动于气根之内，生时有天应星，地应潮，六根震动之状，故曰内药、大药，又曰金丹。 再以此金丹，运起河车，鼓动巽风，施用坤火，合离宫真精而炼之。 真气合真精，即以先天阳气，制伏后天阴精，阴精亦合真气而化为圣胎。 夫真气，自真精而生者也，为子气，气复归精，故喻子投母胎。 所谓子恋母而来，母恋子而住，子母相抱，神气相依。 即内然真火，外用阴符阳火，内外交炼，即结为圣胎，所谓“铅将尽汞亦干，化成一块紫金霜”。 金丹大道与生人异者，只此处处逆施造化，颠倒乾坤耳。 凡有功德，有缘有道之士，遇吾此注，尽可施功，不受异端祸乱。 然而天机尽泄于此，如有助德之人，得天启沃，明白此旨，亦毋得轻泄，致于罪咎焉。
chunks.translated_text:
「Water is light and floats—
This is the **postnatal qi** of the Dao,
Belonging to **external medicine**;

Gold is heavy and sinks—
This is the **prenatal essence** of the Way,
Called **true lead**—
Also called **gold elixir**, also called **the White Tiger’s first crescent breath**,
Its names are manifold—
This is **internal medicine**.

The prenatal gold generates water,
As the **natural order** of **sequential cultivation**,
And births humanity through it—
Thus it is said: *"Heavy as the root of light."*

After birth, humanity is purely
The reckless, turbulent, and light-floating **postnatal qi** at work—
Hence water-qi is light and floats,
Giving rise to manifold passions and desires,
The **essence of life** is lost,
And thus aging and decline come easily.

The **worthy** has the **method of inverse cultivation**—
None other than water returning to generate gold,
Light returning to heavy,
To restore the **original unity of Heaven’s breath**.

Thus, throughout the day,
They move without abandoning the **burden of refinement**—
Only to stand firm and upright,
Stable and uniquely established,
Thick and heavy without wavering,
Nurturing **vast qi** to fill the cosmos.

This is the **Dao of inverse cultivation for immortals**,
Where alchemy is practiced.

In sum: from **form** to **formlessness**,
This is but one matter of the **elixir’s Dao**.

Fire is dry and active—
This is the **postnatal spirit** of the Way,
Belonging to **external medicine**;

Wood is still and congealed—
This is the **prenatal original nature** of the Way,
Called **true mercury**, **true essence**,
Also called **the breath of the Azure Dragon**,
**True Unity’s breath**—
Its names are also many—
All are **internal medicine**.

The prenatal wood generates fire,
As the **natural order** of **sequential cultivation**,
And births humanity through it—
Thus it is said: *"Stillness is the sovereign of agitation."*

After the body takes form,
Purely the **spirit of erratic reasoning and delusion** rules—
Hence fire’s nature is wild and unrestrained,
With manifold deceits and transformations,
Its true essence is bound and obscured,
And thus weakness and collapse come easily.

The **worthy** has the **method of inverted application**—
None other than fire returning to generate wood,
Agitation returning to stillness,
To restore the **original unity of the spirit**.

Though there may be splendor and ease,
And dwelling in lofty detachment—
It is but all phenomena emptied,
One true essence held close—
Nurturing the **awakened True Golden Immortal**,
Summoning the **heavenly realms**—
This is the **elixir’s Dao of inverse refinement**,
Whereby immortality is attained.

In essence: from **awareness** to **formlessness**,
This is another branch of **cultivation**.

This is the refinement of **external medicine** to **internal medicine**,
From **postnatal** back to **prenatal**.

Let me further elucidate:
The **Dao of birth** follows the **natural order**,
The **Dao of immortality** inverts and overcomes it—
For without overcoming, there is no birth,
Nor without overcoming can one attain attainment.
Thus the **River Diagram** and **Luo Scripture** employ both **generation** and **overcoming**.

The **Confucian** and **Buddhist** methods of cultivation differ from mine—
They generally follow the **natural order**,
Conforming to the **degree of spontaneity**;

My **Dao** alone inverts and refines,
Requiring **diligent effort** in its practice.
If one fails to overcome,
There is no way to birth or attain.

But to cultivate in accordance with the **natural order** is easy,
While to invert and refine is difficult.
Without a **true master**,
Unclear of the **correct method**,
And recklessly gathering or refining—
Few escape harm.

Once the **true master** is obtained,
And the **correct method** is clear—
If one does not **seize the opportunity for immortality**,
Nor **cultivate the merit of virtue**,
Then **Heaven’s spirit** will not aid,
And **demonic illusions** will entangle—
There will surely be those who nearly attain but fail,
Whose **elixir collapses**, **cauldron tips over**,
And whose **life and essence are both lost**—
This is truly something to be cautious about.

How does one **invert and overcome**?
First, one follows the **natural order**,
Imitating the **method of husband and wife**,
With **fire entering the domain of water**—
This is **spirit entering qi**,
The **common folk’s father and mother** uniting to produce **medicine**.

When fire steams and water boils,
Gold is born from the depths of water—
At this moment, the **mystic orifice opens**,
And **true faith** arrives—
This is the **true yang** birthing,
And the **medicine-child** is produced—
This is **external medicine**.

Once the **golden-qi** is born,
**True lead** is sufficient—
I, with **fire urging water to ascend**,
**Wood bearing gold aloft**,
Urge it gently, guide it carefully,
Lifting it to the **Heavenly Cauldron**,
To pair **true lead** with **true mercury**,
To use **true fire** and **true intent** to draw it,
Lowering it into the **elixir field**,
Entering the **Earth’s womb**—
Refining the **medicine** with the **cauldron and furnace**,
This is **returning to Kan as male**,
And **restoring Li as female**.

Inverting male and female,
Selecting them as **host and guest**,
Drawing them back into the **furnace**,
Refining them for a **morning’s watch**,
Then awaiting the **true yang fire’s movement**,
To form the **great medicinal fire**—
This is the **birth of internal medicine**,
Also called **the great medicine’s production**.

This is the **sage-father and holy-mother** uniting to nurture.

Moreover, the **small medicine’s** birth,
Its movement lies outside the **kidney passage**,
Its **qi** is weak—
Thus it is called **small medicine, external medicine**;

This one’s movement lies within the **qi’s root**,
When born, there are **heavenly response stars**,
**Earthly response tides**,
And the **six senses tremble**—
Thus it is called **internal medicine, great medicine**,
Also called **gold elixir**.

Again, with this **gold elixir**,
One **stirs the River Vehicle**,
**Stirs the gentle winds**,
Applies the **Earth’s fire**,
And refines the **true essence of the Li Palace**.

When **true qi** merges with **true essence**,
It is the **prenatal yang qi** subduing the **postnatal yin essence**,
And the **yin essence** also merges with **true qi**,
Transforming into the **holy fetus**.

For **true qi** is born from **true essence**,
As **child-qi**—
When **qi** returns to **essence**,
It is likened to **child entering the mother’s womb**.

It is said: *"The child clings to the mother and comes,
The mother clings to the child and remains—
Child and mother embrace,
Spirit and qi depend on each other."*

It is the **internal true fire**,
The **external application of yin-symbol yang-fire**—
When **internal and external** refining occurs,
The **holy fetus** is formed—
As in the saying: *"When lead is nearly exhausted, mercury also dries,
Transformed into one piece of purple gold frost."*

The **great Dao of gold elixir** differs from the **Dao of birth**—
Only in this inversion of **nature’s transformations**,
And overturning of **Heaven and Earth**.

All those with **merit and virtue**,
With **opportunity and Dao**—
Upon encountering my **explanation**,
May all apply the **function**,
Without fear of **heterodox calamities**.

Yet the **Heavenly mechanism** is fully revealed here—
If there are those who **assist in virtue**,
And receive **Heaven’s illumination**,
Understanding this **meaning**—
They must not **lightly disclose** it,
Lest they incur **guilt and blame.»**

chunks.original_text: 至若经云“万乘之主”，即人身中之元神也。 夫人之心，莫不欲一身安泰，百岁康强，奈何知诱物化，欲起情生，而以身轻用于天下也！ 此气虚浮而丧气，此神躁动而失神，身之存者，盖亦鲜矣，何况金丹大道乎？ 此注已将筑基、炼己、结丹、还丹、玉液、小大周天之法则，详细剖明，生等当书缙绅，佩服不忘，庶知之真而行之至也。 由是功成道就，永为天上神仙，不受人间苦恼，岂不甚幸，各宜勉旃！ 第二十七章 常善救人 善行无辙迹，善言无瑕摘，善教不用筹策，善闭无关键而不可开，善结无绳约而不可解。 是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人； 常善救物，故无弃物。 是谓袭明。 故善人者不善人之师； 不善人者善人之资。 不贵其师，不爱其资，虽智大迷。 是谓要妙 圣人之心，只求诸己，不求诸人。 其施之于事物也，无为不通，随在皆当，内无歉于己，外无恶于人。 《易》所谓“时止则止，时行则行，动静不失其时，其道光明”，殆斯人欤？ 其于行也，时而可行，行之而已。 前不见其所来，后不见其所往，抑何辙迹之俱无哉！ 其行之善有如此。 其于言也，时当可言，言之而已。 内不见辱于己，外不贻羞于人，如何瑕摘之悉化哉！ 其言之善有如此。 至于物之当计，事之宜筹，揆之以理，度之以情，顺理而施，如情而止，宜多则多，当少则少，何须筹策之劳！ 即此因应无心，物我俱化，非善计而何？ 更有宜闭宜结之事，其在他人不闭则乱，不结则散，而圣人外缘悉绝，内念不生，完完全全，非所谓善闭者乎？ 虽无绳约之束，关键之防，而无隙可乘，俨若弥缝甚固，其不可开不可解也。 不诚天理浑全，无懈可击耶？ 之数者，殆顺乎自然之天，不参以人为之伪，故其效如此。 要皆内修而外慕，自正而无它求。 所以立己立人，人无遗类； 成己成物，物无弃材。 其济人利物之善为何如者！ 是皆自明明德，又推之以理民及物，不谓之重袭其明哉？ 然而善人初不自知也，善人浑忘物我，故不善者感之而尊为师。 善人亦不自满也，见不善人，善人即以之为资，见善则从，不善则改——善人所由益进于善而至于美大化神之域焉。 若凡人自恃其才，自逞其能，见善者置之不问，不知奉以为模； 不善者弃之如遗，反鄙之而不屑，不知见贤思齐，不贤内省，善恶虽殊，而为己之师资则一也。 似此不贵其师，不爱其资，殆愚而好自用，贱而好自专者，不诚昏昧人哉？ 夫善者师之，恶者戒之。 随在皆有益于己，无人不有益于身。 是诚修己之要术，治身之妙道也，人其勉之！ 此见圣人之语，无所不通。 事物之理，即性命之道，体用原是兼赅，本末由来不离。 如云善行无瑕迹，推之气机流行，河车自运，亦是如此。 若有迹象，即属搬运存想，非自在河车，上合天道之流行。 曰“善言无暇摘”，即无法可说，是名说法，又曰祖师西来意。 孔子曰：“天何言哉，四时行焉，百物生焉。 ”有瑕可摘，即有言可见，非圣人心领神会之宗旨。 释氏曰“道本无言，却被人说坏了”，是其意矣。 曰“善计无筹策”，周天之数，不过喻名三百之数，实非有爻策可计； 有则非自然火候。 曰“善闭无关键”，本是鸿蒙未破，元神默默，元气冥冥，返还于元始之初，以结胎而成圣。

「Then the scripture speaks of *"the sovereign of ten thousand chariots"*—
This is the **original spirit** within the human body.

All people’s hearts desire
A single body’s peace and security,
A hundred years of vigor and strength—
Yet how can they know to **induce transformations**,
To **arouse emotions** and **generate life**,
While **lightly expending** their bodies in the world?

This **qi** is **hollow and floating**, thus **losing qi**;
This **spirit** is **agitated and restless**, thus **losing spirit**—
If the body’s survival is already scarce,
How much more so the **Dao of gold elixir**?

This **explanation** has already laid out
The **principles** of **foundation-building**, **self-refinement**, **forming the elixir**, **returning the elixir**, **jade nectar**, and the **small and great cosmic cycles**—
Detailed and clarified.
Those who follow the **Way of life**,
Who are **scholars and officials**,
Should cherish and never forget it—
Thus knowing its truth and practicing it to perfection.

Through this, **achievement and Dao** are attained,
And one becomes forever a **celestial immortal**,
Free from the **sufferings of the mortal world**—
Is this not most fortunate?
All should strive accordingly!

**Chapter Twenty-Seventh: Constantly Do Good to Save Others**
**Good deeds** leave no **traces** to be followed,
**Good words** bear no **flaws** to be censured,
**Good instruction** requires no **plans or strategies**,
**Good concealment** has no **locks or keys** yet cannot be opened,
**Good binding** has no **ropes or knots** yet cannot be undone.

Thus the **sage** constantly does good to save others,
And so **never abandons anyone**;
Constantly does good to save all things,
And so **never discards anything**.

This is called **"inheriting clarity."**

Therefore, the **good person** is the **teacher** of the **not-good**,
And the **not-good** is the **resource** of the **good**.
If one does not **honor their teacher**,
And does not **cherish their resource**,
Even great wisdom may lead to **great confusion**.

This is called **"the essential subtlety."**

The **sage’s heart** seeks only within themselves,
Not in others.

In their **application to affairs and things**,
They act without **non-action**—
Whatever arises, they respond accordingly,
With no **deficiency within**,
And no **harm done to others without**.

As the *Yijing* says:
*"When the time is to stop, one stops;
When the time is to act, one acts—
In **motion and stillness**, one does not lose the **proper timing**,
Their **Dao** is **radiant and clear**."*
Is this not such a person?

In their **conduct**, when the time is right to act,
They simply act—
No **trace** of their origin before,
No **path** of their destination behind—
How could **traces** possibly remain?

Their **conduct’s goodness** is such.

In their **words**, when the time is right to speak,
They simply speak—
No **humiliation** seen within themselves,
No **shame** left for others—
How could **flaws** possibly persist?

Their **words’ goodness** is such.

As for **matters requiring calculation**,
And **affairs needing strategy**—
Measured by **reason**,
Judged by **sentiment**,
Following **reason** to apply,
Conforming to **sentiment** to halt—
When much is fitting, much is done;
When little is fitting, little is done—
Why bother with **planning and scheming**?
This **responsive action without deliberation**,
Where **self and others dissolve**—
Is this not the **good calculation**?

Further, there are **matters requiring closure and binding**—
For others, if not **closed**, there is **chaos**;
If not **bound**, there is **dispersion**—
Yet the **sage** cuts off all **external connections**,
And **no internal thoughts** arise—
**Perfect and complete**, is this not the **good concealment**?

Though there are no **ropes or knots** to constrain,
No **locks or keys** to guard—
Yet there is no **gap** for others to exploit,
As if **sealed tightly and unassailable**,
Their **impenetrability** is such.
Is this not the **sincere unity of Heavenly principle**,
With **no vulnerabilities** to be seized?

This **number** of ways—
They follow **natural Heaven**, untainted by human **artifice**,
And so their effects are such.

Essentially, **internal cultivation** and **external emulation**,
**Self-correction** without **other demands**—
This is how one **establishes themselves and others**,
With **no one left behind**;
This is how one **perfects themselves and things**,
With **no talent wasted**.

Their **benevolence in saving and benefiting others**—
How could it be otherwise?

This is all from **self-illuminating virtue**,
And **extending it** to **govern people and things**—
Is this not **reiterating their clarity**?

Yet the **good person** initially does not **know themselves**—
The **good person** **forgets** **self and others**,
Thus the **not-good** are **moved** and **revere them as teacher**.
The **good person** is also not **self-satisfied**—
Seeing the **not-good**, the **good person** takes them as **resource**,
Following what is **good** and correcting what is **not**—
Thus the **good person** **advances in goodness**,
Until they reach the **domain of supreme transformation and divine change**.

If **common folk** **rely on their own abilities**,
**Boast of their own skills**—
Seeing the **good**, they **ignore** them as if nothing,
Not knowing to **revere them as models**;
Seeing the **not-good**, they **discard** them as if they were trash,
Even **despising** them and deeming them unworthy—
Not knowing *"to see the virtuous and strive to equal them,
To see the unvirtuous and reflect inward"*—
Though **good and evil** differ,
Their **teachers and resources** for **self** remain the same.

Such as this—
Not **honoring their teacher**,
Not **cherishing their resource**—
Are they not the **foolish and self-indulgent**,
The **lowly and self-absorbed**?
Are they not truly the **bewildered**?

**Goodness** is **learned from teachers**,
**Evil** is **warned against**—
Whatever arises is **beneficial to oneself**,
No person lacks **benefit to the body**.

This is truly the **essential method of self-cultivation**,
The **wonderful Dao of bodily governance**—
All should **strive** accordingly!

This **understanding of the sage’s words** is **universally applicable**.
The **principles of affairs and things**,
Are the **Dao of life and death**—
**Substance and function** are inherently **unified**,
**Root and branch** originally **inseparable**.

As said, **good conduct** leaves no **traces**—
Extended to the **flow of spiritual qi**,
The **River Vehicle** moving **on its own**—
This is also so.

If there are **traces or signs**,
It belongs to **forced manipulation and deliberate meditation**—
Not the **free movement of the River Vehicle**,
Nor the **natural alignment with Heaven’s Dao**.

It says *"good words bear no flaws"*—
Meaning **no laws can be spoken**, this is called **Dharma transmission**,
Or *"the intent of the Ancestral Teachers from the West."*

Confucius said:
*"How does Heaven speak?
The **four seasons** move in their course,
The **ten thousand things** come to life."*

If there are **flaws to be censured**,
It means there are **words visible**—
Not the **sage’s silent comprehension and spiritual resonance**.

The **Buddhist School** says:
*"The **Dao** is originally **without words**,
Yet people have **spoken it into ruin**."*
This is its meaning.

It says *"good calculation requires no scheming"*—
The **numbers of the cosmic cycle**,
Are merely **symbolic names** for **three hundred transformations**,
In truth, there are no **hexagrams or strategies** to calculate;
If there are, they are not **natural fire and timing**.

It says *"good concealment has no locks"*—
This is the **original chaos** unbroken,
The **original spirit** **silent and motionless**,
The **original qi** **obscure and still**,
Returning to the **beginning of the Primordial Origin**,
To **bind the fetus** and thus become **sage**.

chunks.original_text: 若有闭则有开，非内炼之道也。 曰“善结无绳约”，言神恋气而凝，命依性而住。 神气吻合，复还太极，以结成黍米之珠，阳神之体。 若有则勉强撮合，非自然之凝聚，而不可以复命归真，顾其功效如此。 而修养之要，不过见善则迁，有过则改，取法乎善与不善之类，返观内省以为功也。 倘矜才恃智，傲法凌人，不贵其师，不爱其资，纵有才智，亦愚昧之夫，终不足以入道矣。 于此见修道之要妙，圣凡原同一辙焉。 第二十八章 常德不离 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪； 为天下溪，常德不离，复归于婴儿。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式； 为天下式，常德不忒，复归于无极。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷； 为天下谷，常德乃足，复归于朴。 朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长。 故大制不割。 修炼之道，气从阳生。 运转河车，行凭子午。 到得铅气抽尽，汞精已足，是铅汞会合为一气，此既得雄归以合丹，尤要伏雌以养丹。 故曰：“知其雄，守其雌。 ”夫雄，阳也； 雌，阴也。 阴阳和合，雌雄交感，而金藏于水； 复水又生金，金气足而潮信至，其势有如溪涧然，自上注下，犹溪涧之所蓄糜穷。 修行人知阳不生于阳而生于阴，故不守雄而守雌。 久之微阳渐生，阴滓悉化，而归根复命之常德，不可一息偶离。 从此阴阳交媾，结成仙胎，于是逐日温养以成婴儿，有必然者。 《悟真》云“雄里怀雌结圣胎”是也。 既铅汞会合，打成一片，复将此交媾之精，养于坤宫煅炼，真铅生矣。 此谓知其白守其黑。 夫白，精也； 黑，水也。 此精未产之日，坤体本虚，因上与乾交，坤实为坎。 是水中金生，赖坤母以养成，故称母气。 《悟真》云“黑中取白为丹母”是也。 得到真铅既至，即运一点己汞以迎之。 左提右挈，静候白虎首经。 果听地下雷鸣，实有丹心贯日、浩气凌霄之状，我仍守我虚无窟子，不稍惊惶，此即炼精化气时也。 以后运辘轳，升三车，由夹脊双关上至泥丸，行子午卯酉四正之工，合春夏秋冬四时之序，此即为天下式。 凡人物之生长收藏，亦无丝毫差忒不与天合变焉。 由是上升下降，送归土釜，化有象以还无象，复归无极之天。 此大周天之候，玉液之丹，即在此矣。 斯时也，金丹既归玄窍，复合青龙真一之气，炼成不二元神，此即炼气化神时也。 再修向上一层，炼神还虚之道——惟混混沌沌，涵养虚无； 浑浑沦沦，完全理气； 化识成智，浑圣如愚。
chunks.translated_text:
「If there is **closing**, there must be **opening**—
This is not the **Dao** of **internal cultivation**.

It says *"good binding requires no cord or constraint"*—
The **spirit** clings to the **qi** and congeals,
The **life** depends on the **nature** and abides.
When **spirit and qi** embrace,
They return to the **Primordial Pole (Tai Ji)**,
Binding into a **rice-grain-sized pearl**—
The **body of the Yang Spirit**.

If there is **artificial binding**, it is forced together,
Not the **natural coalescence** of the **qi**,
And thus cannot **restore life and return to the true self**—
Yet its **effects** are as described.

The **essence of cultivation and nourishment** lies simply in:
*"Seeing the good, one shifts toward it;
Encountering faults, one corrects them."*
Taking **patterns from the good and the bad**,
And **reflecting inwardly** as the **method**.

If one **boasts of talent** and **relies on wisdom**,
**Disdains the Dao** and **tramples others**,
Holds no **reverence for the teacher**,
Nor **cherishes the resources**,
Even with **talent and wisdom**,
One remains a **foolish and ignorant man**,
And will **never attain the Dao**.

Here lies the **subtle essence of cultivation**—
The **sage and the common man** share the **same path**.

**Chapter Twenty-Eighth: Constant Virtue Never Departs**

*"Know its **masculine** aspect, hold to its **feminine** aspect,
To become the **valley of the world**;
To become the **valley of the world**,
**Constant virtue** never departs,
And returns to the **infant state**.

*Know its **white**, hold to its **black**,
To become the **model of the world**;
To become the **model of the world**,
**Constant virtue** remains unerring,
And returns to the **Primordial Non-Polarity (Wu Ji)**.

*Know its **prosperity**, hold to its **humiliation**,
To become the **abyss of the world**;
To become the **abyss of the world**,
**Constant virtue** is then complete,
And returns to **primordial simplicity (Pu)**."*

**Pu** disperses to form **vessels**;
The **sage** employs them as **officials and leaders**.
Thus, the **great method** is never severed.

In the **Dao of cultivation and refinement**,
**Qi** originates from the **Yang**.
Operating the **River Wheel (He Che)**, proceeding by **Child-Midnight (Zi-Wu)**.
When the **lead-qi** is fully extracted,
And the **mercury-essence** is sufficient,
This is when **lead and mercury merge into one qi**—
Now, **merging the masculine** to **refine the elixir**,
But **suppressing the feminine** to **nourish the elixir** is even more crucial.

Hence it says: *"Know its **masculine**, hold to its **feminine**."*

The **masculine** is **Yang**;
The **feminine** is **Yin**.
When **Yin and Yang** harmonize,
And **masculine and feminine** resonate,
The **metal is hidden within the water**;
Then **water again generates metal**—
When the **metal-qi** is abundant,
The **tidal signals** arrive.
Its **momentum** is like a **valley and ravine**,
Flowing from above to below,
Just as the **valley and ravine** accumulate and overflow.

The **practitioner** knows that **Yang does not generate from Yang alone**,
But from **Yin**—
Thus, one does not **hold to the masculine** but **holds to the feminine**.

Over time, **subtle Yang gradually emerges**,
And the **Yin dross** is fully transformed,
Returning to the **constant virtue of restoring the root and life**,
Which **cannot be momentarily separated**.

From here, **Yin and Yang** intermingle,
Binding into the **immortal fetus**,
And thus **daily tempering and nourishing** to form the **infant**—
This is inevitable.
The *Wù Zhēn* says: *"Nurturing the feminine within the masculine to bind the sacred fetus"*—
This is it.

Once **lead and mercury** have merged,
And become **one unified essence**,
This **intermingling essence** is then **nourished in the Kūn Palace** (Kun Gong) for **refinement**,
And **true lead** is born.

This is called *"knowing its **white** and holding to its **black**"*.
The **white** is the **essence**;
The **black** is the **water**.

Before the **essence** is produced,
The **Kūn body** is inherently **void**—
When it **interacts with the Kān (Heavenly Water)**,
The **Kūn void** becomes **Kān (Abyssal Water)**.
Thus, **metal is born within the water**,
And relies on the **Kūn Mother** to **nourish and complete** it,
Hence it is called **mother-qi**.
The *Wù Zhēn* says: *"Extracting the white from the black as the elixir-mother"*—
This is it.

Once **true lead** is obtained,
One **activates a droplet of one’s own mercury** to greet it.
With **left hand lifting and right hand drawing**,
One **quietly awaits the White Tiger’s head** (Bai Hu Shou Jing).
If one **truly hears the thunderous rumblings from below**,
There is the **state of the elixir-heart piercing the day**,
And the **vast-qi towering above the heavens**—
I **still hold to my void and still abode**,
**Not the slightest agitation**,
This is the **time of refining essence into qi**.

Afterward, **operating the wheel**,
Ascending the **three vehicles (sānrú)**,
From the **double gates (shuāngguān)** of the **sacral spine**,
Up to the **mud pellet (nìwán)**,
Following the **four cardinal processes (Zi-Wu-Mao-You)**,
And **harmonizing the sequence of the four seasons**—
This is the **model of the world**.

All **birth, growth, contraction, and concealment** of **humans and things**,
Also **do not differ in the slightest** from the **heavenly transformations**.

From this, **ascending and descending**,
Sending it back to the **earthly cauldron** (tǔfǔ),
Transforming **manifest forms** into **non-manifest forms**,
And returning to the **Primordial Non-Polarity (Wu Ji)** of the **Heaven**.
This is the **moment of the Great Heavenly Cycle**—
The **jade-fluid elixir** is here.

At this time,
The **golden elixir** returns to the **mysterious orifice** (Xuànqiào),
And **merges with the true-one qi of the Azure Dragon** (Qīnglóng Zhēnyī),
Refining into the **non-dual Primordial Spirit**—
This is the **time of refining qi into spirit**.

In the **next layer of cultivation**—
The **Dao of refining spirit back to void**—
Only **mysterious and chaotic**,
**Nourishing the void and stillness**;
**Turbulent and profound**,
**Perfectly uniting principle and qi**;
**Transforming perception into wisdom**,
**Merging sagehood with foolishness.**»

chunks.original_text: 一日一夜，言不轻发，心无它思，有如椎鲁之夫，毫无知见。 纵有侮辱频来，俨若不识不知，一如舜之居深山，无异于深山野人焉。 此即知成人之荣，守成仙之辱也。 不如此不足以养虚合道。 故曰：“开口神气散，意乱火功寒。 能知归复法，金宝重如山。 ”若妄发一言，妄生一念，即同走丹。 道愈高，势愈险。 炼丹到此，尤为危险之地，是以古人道果圆成之后，装聋卖哑，作颠放狂，殆为养虚合道计也。 否亦何乐为此耶？ 所以心中无一物，实为天下谷。 既为天下谷，尤须意冷于冰，心清似水，而真常之玄德，于此方能充足。 然而真空不空，妙有不有。 始而从无入有，继而从有归无，终则有无不立。 此所以由太极而复归浑朴，返本还原之道得矣。 虽然，其聚则一，其散则万。 以至生生不已，化化不穷，何莫非器之所在； 亦何莫非朴之所散！ 此朴散为器之说也。 而圣人用之，不尚器而散朴，殆谓虚寂为一身之主宰，万变之总持，犹人世官长无二。 又曰“大制不割”者何？ 盖以浑然之道，范围不过，曲成不遗，足为宰制之需； 若或割焉，亦是矫揉造作，初非本来性天。 圣人不割，亦还其混沌之天而已。 学者知之否？ 此合孔德之容章并看，则知化精、化气、化神之旨，尽于此矣。 虽然，其中细密处吾不妨再言之：“昔日逢师亲口诀，只要凝神入气穴。 ”若非回光返照丹田，则金水必然浑浊。 既知凝神坤宫，或作辍不常，则水火必然散漫，先天真一之气又从何生？ 虽然，修炼之法，凝神要矣，而调息亦不可少焉。 苟知神凝气穴，而不知调呼吸之息，下入阴蹻穴中，则神虽住而息不畅，无以扇风动火，使凡息停而真息见，凡心死而真心生。 又况神火全凭神息，若无神息吹嘘，不惟水火不清，亦且金胎不化。 既凝神调息，知所归宿矣，尤要神融气畅之际，如天未开，冥冥晦晦，然后一切游思浊气，方能收拾干净，犹日月剥蚀一番，自有一番新气象，如此絪絪缊缊，于无知觉时，忽然有知有觉，即是太极开基，玄关现象，又是一阳初动处，万物始生时。 此际能把得住，拿得定，正所谓捉雾拿云手段。 丹经云“时至神知”，又云“真活子时”，正谓此也。 此时即当采取，若稍晷刻，又起后天知觉之私，不堪为金丹之药矣。 此个机关，总要于万缘放下，一念不起时，急以真意寻之，方得真清药物。 总要静之又静，沉之又沉，于无知无觉时，寻有知有觉处，庶乎得之。 既曰一念不起，又何事用意去寻？ 岂不是有意去寻，又落后天识神乎？ 殊不知此个真意，如种火然，不见有火而火自在，不过机动而神随，自然之感触有如此者。 若谓真属有意，则落于固执。 若谓真果无意，又随于顽空。 此有意无意之间，学人当自会之。 《易》曰“寂然不动，感而遂通”是也。 如此方是真知真觉，要皆真意为之。 虽然，真意由于真心，必其心空洞了灵，不以有物而增，无物而减。 有此真心，方有真意。 有此真意，乃有真息。 总要具有慧照，不错机宜，则炼一次自有一次之长益。 到此地步，常常采取，自有真阳发生，还要炼己待时，不可略有一点求动之心，则后天识神不来夹杂，即先天至阳之精，真一之气。 久久熏蒸积累，自有大药发生，可以返老还童。
chunks.translated_text:
「A single day and night,
Speak not lightly, think not otherwise—
Like a dullard husband, utterly without perception.
Even if insults come again and again,
Stand as if unaware, as if ignorant—
Just as Shun dwelt in the deep mountains,
No different from a wild man of the hills.
This is the **honor of the perfected human**,
The **humiliation of the perfected sage**.

Without this, one cannot **nourish the void** and **align with the Dao**.
Thus it is said:
*"Speak, and the spirit-qi scatters;
The mind in turmoil, the fire of cultivation grows cold.
He who knows the **Law of Return**—
His golden treasure weighs like mountains."*

If one speaks recklessly, if one harbors a single thought,
It is like fleeing the elixir.
The **Dao grows higher, the path grows more perilous**.
At this stage of elixir refinement, it is the most dangerous ground—
Hence, ancient sages, after attaining fruition,
Feigned deafness and madness, acted as fools and lunatics—
All for the sake of **nourishing the void** and **aligning with the Dao**.
Why else would they endure such suffering?

Thus, the mind must hold nothing—
This is the **valley of the world**.
As the **valley of the world**, it must be colder than ice,
Clearer than water,
And only then will the **eternal mysterious virtue** be fully realized.

Yet **true emptiness is not emptiness, subtle being is not being**.
First, from **non-being to being**,
Then from **being back to non-being**,
Finally, where **being and non-being stand not at all**.
This is the **Dao of returning to the Primordial Simplicity** from the **Great Polarization (Tai Ji)**,
The **Way of restoring the origin and returning to the root**.

Though it **converges into one**, it **disperses into ten thousand**.
Thus, **endless generation**, **endless transformation**—
Where is not the **vessel** present?
Where is not the **Primordial Simplicity** dispersed?
This is the **saying of the Primordial Simplicity dispersing into vessels**.

The sage employs this—
Not valuing the vessel but dispersing the Primordial Simplicity—
For **emptiness and stillness** are the **master of the body**,
The **total holder of all transformations**,
Like the sole authority in the world of men.
It is also said, *"The great measure does not cut"*—
For the **Dao in its wholeness** encompasses all without omission,
Fulfills all without excess—
Sufficient for governance.
If one were to **cut into it**, it would be artificial contrivance,
Not the original **nature of Heaven**.
The sage does not cut—
Only returns to the **Primordial Chaos of Heaven**.

Do the students understand?
When viewed alongside the **chapter on Confucius’ virtue**, one sees
The essence of **refining essence, refining qi, refining spirit** is all here.

Still, its subtleties must be further explained:
*"In days past, the master’s oral instruction:
Only **concentrate the spirit** and enter the **qi-cavity**."*

If one does not **return the light and illuminate the elixir field (Dan Tian)**,
The **golden water** will surely become turbid.
Once one knows to **concentrate the spirit in the Kūn Palace (the lower elixir field)**,
Yet sometimes **halts and does not persist**,
The **water and fire** will scatter—
Where then will the **true-one qi of the Primordial Heaven** arise?

Though **concentrating the spirit** is essential,
**Regulating the breath** must not be neglected.
If one knows to **concentrate the spirit in the qi-cavity**
But does not know to **adjust the inhalation and exhalation**,
Descending into the **Yin-latch orifice (Yin Kēi)**,
Though the spirit may dwell, the breath will not flow freely—
Without **fanning the wind and stirring the fire**,
The **common breath** will stagnate while the **true breath** emerges,
The **common mind** will die while the **true mind** is born.

Moreover, the **true fire** depends entirely on the **true breath**—
Without the **true breath** to fan it,
Not only will the **water and fire** remain unclean,
But the **golden embryo** will fail to refine.

Once the **spirit is concentrated** and the **breath is regulated**,
One knows where to **return**—
At the moment when the **spirit is harmonized** and the **qi is unobstructed**,
As if **Heaven has not yet opened**,
Dark and indistinct—
Only then can all **wandering thoughts and turbid qi** be gathered and purified,
Like the **eclipse of the sun and moon**, revealing a new vitality.
Thus, **thread by thread, weave by weave**,
At the moment of **no awareness**,
Suddenly there is **awareness**—
This is the **foundation of the Great Polarization (Tai Ji)**,
The **manifestation of the Mysterious Pass (Xuàn Guān)**,
The **first stir of the Primordial Yang**.
At this moment, if one can **grasp it firmly, hold it steadily**,
This is the **technique of seizing mist and catching clouds**.

The **Dan Jing** says, *"When the time arrives, the spirit knows,"*
And again, *"The true child is alive"*—
This is precisely what is meant.

At this moment, one must **seize it immediately**—
If even a moment is delayed,
The **post-heaven awareness** will arise again,
And it will no longer be fit for the **golden elixir**.

This **critical juncture** must be grasped
When all **affiliations are abandoned** and **not a single thought arises**—
Only then can the **true intention** find it,
And the **true pure medicine** be obtained.

It must be **stillness upon stillness,沉沉沉沉 (sinking deeper and deeper)**—
At the moment of **no awareness, no perception**,
One seeks **awareness and perception**—
Only then may it be attained.

If it is said, *"Not a single thought arises,"*
Then why seek with the **intention**?
Is it not that **intentionally seeking** falls into **post-heaven awareness and spirit**?

Yet the **true intention** is like **hidden fire**—
Though unseen, the fire is present.
It is merely **triggered by the mechanism**, and the spirit follows naturally—
Such is the **spontaneous response**.

If one says the **true intention is indeed intentional**,
It falls into **rigidity**.
If one says the **true intention is truly without intention**,
It falls into **empty vacuity**.

Between **intention and no intention**, the student must **understand it naturally**.

The *Yijing* says:
*"Motionless and still,
Yet responsive and penetrating."*
Only then is it **true knowing, true awareness**—
All done by the **true intention**.

Though the **true intention** arises from the **true heart**,
The heart must be **empty, luminous, and responsive**—
Neither increased by **having** nor decreased by **lacking**.
With this **true heart**, there is **true intention**.
With this **true intention**, there is **true breath**.

One must possess **enlightened illumination**,
Never missing the **opportune moment**—
Then each refinement will bring its own **growth and benefit**.

At this stage, if one **constantly seizes the moment**,
The **true yang** will naturally arise—
Still, one must **refine oneself and await the time**,
Not daring to harbor even a **trace of seeking movement**,
Lest the **post-heaven awareness and spirit** intrude—
Then the **Primordial Heaven’s utmost yang essence**,
The **true-one qi**,
Will, through **long-term cultivation and accumulation**,
Naturally produce the **great medicine**—
Capable of **returning youth and reversing aging.**»

chunks.original_text: 只怕不肯积功累行，以立外功。 敦伦饬纪，以修内德，无以为承受之基耳。 俗云：不怕一，只怕积。 不怕骤，只怕凑。 诚哉是言也。 学人欲知用意之道，切勿徒听自然焉可。 第二十九章 去奢去泰 将欲取天下而为之，吾见其不得已。 天下神器，不可为也，不可执也。 为者败之，执者失之。 故物或行或随，或呴或吹，或强或羸。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 道本无声无臭，清净自然。 修道者亦当不识不知，纯任自然，此历代祖师心印，自开辟以至于今，无可或外者。 无如世之异端旁门，反讥吾道为孤修寂炼，卒至顽空无用，我岂不自思哉？ 将欲取天下而行有为之政，吾见其不为而不得已，愈为而愈不得已也。 盖天下虽大，原有神器为之先。 所谓先天大道，希言自然者是。 天下为神器之匡廓，神器乃天下之主宰，天下可为而神器不可为也。 苟有为焉，始则纷更多事，究至荡检逾闲，而天德尽废，为之正所以败之也。 审是与其有为而偾事，何如无为而成功乎！ 与其有执而失常，何如无执而得道乎！ 况道原于天，天道无为，而自化生其中者，又何异耶？ 试观初生之时，乾元资始，或阳往而行先； 坤元资生，或阴来而随后。 一动一静，互为其根，有必然者。 他如气之由伸而屈，吸之则油然而呴； 气之由屈而伸，呼之则悠然而吹。 如是则生气畅，生机永矣。 至于禀受不同，刚柔亦异，或受气多而精强，或受气少而精弱，要皆后天之不齐。 物生之各别，故有时而伸，气机蓬勃上载； 有时而降，气机油然下隳。 是皆天道之自然，非人力所可致也。 虽下手之初，不无勉强之迹，然亦因其势顺其时，可行则行，可止则止，勉强中寓自然，固久远而不弊耳。 是亦圣人于采药炼丹时，要知去其已甚，去其太奢，去其过泰，在在归于中正，时时处以和平。 虽曰有为，而亦等于无为矣； 虽曰有作，而亦同无作矣。 故有无相生，始可言大道。 此言大道无为——无为者，先天养性之学； 然亦有为——有为者，后天炼命之工。 须知有为无为，性命之修持名异而其中之主宰，总不可偶动，动则非中。 无论有为不是，无为亦非。 惟有中主而不乱，知时识势，见可而进，知难则退，则无为得矣，即有为亦得焉。 主宰者何？ 即天下之神器是也。 人能知得本原，一归浑浑沦沦，虚灵不昧。 始而有为，有为也是； 终则无为，无为也是。 不然概曰无为自然，则孔子何必言道，何必言困之勉行，何必言择善固执？ 知修身之道，端在性命； 性命之功，须分安勉，不必强为分别，总在人神明其德。 如治国然：治则用文，乱则用武，相时而动，听天而行，庶乎左右逢源，无在不得其宜矣。 第此可为知者道，难为板滞者言也。 第三十章 故善者果 以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下，其事好还：师之所处，荆棘生焉，大兵之后，必有凶年。 故善者果而已，不敢以取强。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而不得已，果而勿强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 上古之世，各君其国，各忆其民，熙熙皞皞，共安无事之天； 人己浑忘，畛域胥化，又焉有战争之事哉？ 迨共工作乱而征伐起，蚩尤犯上而兵革兴。 于是文则有玉帛，武则有兵戎； 治则用礼乐，乱则用干戈，朝廷所以文武并重也。
chunks.translated_text:
「One must fear only **not** being willing to **accumulate merit and practice diligence**—
To **establish external cultivation** would be vain.
**Uphold propriety and rectify customs**—
To **cultivate inner virtue** is the only foundation for reception.

The common saying goes:
*"One fears not the single act, but the accumulation;
One fears not the sudden, but the forced combination."*
Truly, these words are profound.

Students who wish to grasp the **Dao/Way’s purpose** must not merely listen to the claim that **"nature alone suffices."**

**Chapter Twenty-Ninth: Removing Excess and Extremity**
*"If one seeks to take the world and act to do so,
I see it as a matter of necessity, not choice.*
*The world is a **divine instrument**—
It cannot be **willed** nor **grasped**.
To **will** it is to **undermine** it;
To **grasp** it is to **lose** it.
Thus, things either **act** or **follow**, **draw in** or **expel**, **strengthen** or **weaken**.
Therefore, the **Sage** removes the **excessive**, the **luxurious**, the **extreme**—
The **Dao/Way** is inherently **soundless and odorless**, pure and serene by nature.
Those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** must also **not know and not perceive**,
Purely yielding to **nature**—
This is the **mind-seal** of all ancestors, from the **Primordial Beginning** to this day,
Unalterable and beyond deviation.

Yet, how unlike the **heterodox sects and false schools** of the world!
They mock our **Dao/Way**, calling it **solitary cultivation of emptiness and refinement**,
Ultimately leading to **barren voidness and uselessness**—
How could I not ponder this?
*"If one seeks to take the world and enforce **artificial governance**,
I see it as a matter of necessity, not choice—
The more one enforces, the more one is driven to necessity."*
Indeed, though the world be vast,
Its **divine framework** is what precedes it.
The **Primordial Dao/Way** is the **silent natural**—
The world is the **divine instrument’s** boundary;
The **divine instrument** is the **world’s sovereign**—
The world may be **willed**, but the **divine instrument** may not.

If one **wills** it,
At first, there will be **chaos and many affairs**,
And in the end, **moral collapse and transgression**,
While **Heaven’s virtue** is utterly abandoned—
This is precisely how **willing** leads to **undermining**.

Consider: **Artificial governance** brings ruin,
But **non-action** achieves success—
**Grasping** disrupts the **constant**,
Yet **non-grasping** attains the **Dao/Way**—
How much more so, since the **Dao/Way** originates from **Heaven**,
And **Heaven’s Dao/Way** is **non-action**,
While **spontaneous transformation** arises within it—
How could it be otherwise?

Observe the time of birth:
The **Primordial Yang** (*乾元*) initiates creation—
Sometimes **yang** departs and **action** precedes;
Sometimes **yin** arrives and **following** comes after.
**Motion** and **stillness** mutually root each other,
With **inevitability** in their nature.

As for **qi**—
When it **expands**, it naturally **contracts**;
When it **draws in**, it naturally **expels**—
**吸** then **呴** arises effortlessly;
**呼** then **吹** unfolds serenely.
Thus, **vital breath** flows freely,
And **life-force** endures eternally.

Yet, **endowments and receptions** differ—
**Strength** and **softness** are not the same—
Some receive **abundant qi** and possess **vigorous essence**,
Others receive **sparse qi** and have **weakened essence**—
All these are **post-heaven disparities**.

Since things are born with their own distinctions,
Sometimes they **ascend**, their **qi-machinery** flourishing upward,
Sometimes they **descend**, their **qi-machinery** naturally collapsing downward—
All these are the **natural workings of Heaven’s Dao/Way**,
Not something **human effort** can force.

Though at the **initial stage** there may be traces of **coercion**,
Yet one must follow its **momentum** and **timing**—
**Act** when it can be done,
**Cease** when it must be stopped—
**Coercion** within **yielding to nature**,
Which remains **unfailing** over the long term.

This is also what the **Sage** knows when **harvesting medicine and refining elixir**—
In all things, **remove the already excessive**,
**Remove the too luxurious**,
**Remove the too extreme**—
Always returning to **moderation**,
Always maintaining **harmony**.

Though it may be said **"artificial governance" exists**,
It is also the same as **"non-action"**;
Though it may be said **"action occurs"**, it is also the same as **"non-action"**.

Thus, **having and not-having mutually generate**,
Only then can one speak of the **Great Dao/Way**.

This is the **Great Dao/Way of non-action**—
**Non-action** refers to the **study of nurturing the Primordial** (*先天养性*);
Yet it is also **action**—
**Action** refers to the **craft of refining the post-heaven** (*后天炼命*).

One must know that **action and non-action**,
Though their **cultivation methods** differ,
The **sovereign principle** within them must never be **disturbed**—
If **disturbed**, it is **not moderation**.
Whether **action** or **non-action**,
Both are **not** the **Dao/Way**.

Only when the **sovereign principle** remains **unshaken and undisturbed**,
Knowing **timing and discerning momentum**,
Advancing when **opportunity** presents,
Retreating when **difficulty** arises—
Then **non-action** is achieved,
And **action** is also attained.

What is the **sovereign principle**?
It is the **divine instrument of the world**.

If humans can **grasp its origin**,
And **return** to the **undifferentiated and unfathomable**,
**Empty and luminous** without **obscurity**—
At first, **action** is **action**,
And at the end, **non-action** is **non-action**.

Otherwise, if one **universally claims** that **"non-action is natural"**, then why did **Confucius** bother to speak of **Dao/Way**?
Why did he speak of **necessity’s diligent practice**?
Why did he speak of **choosing virtue and firmly holding it**?

Knowing the **method of self-cultivation**,
Its **foundation** lies in **nurturing life and essence**—
The **cultivation of life and essence** requires **rest and effort**,
Not **forcibly distinguishing** between them—
All depends on **human discernment** of its **virtue/power**.

As in **governing the state**:
**Peace** is maintained through **ritual and music**,
**Chaos** is suppressed through **arms and warfare**—
**Responding to seasons** and **acting in accordance with Heaven**,
Then **success** will surely come—
**Left and right** will **flow like a source**,
And in all things, **fitness** will be found.

This is the **Dao/Way** that can be spoken to the **wise**,
But is **difficult** for the **rigid and dull-witted** to grasp.

**Chapter Thirtieth: The Fruit of Virtue**
*"Aiding a ruler with the **Dao/Way**,
One does not **coerce the world with arms**—
Such **endeavors** tend to **return in kind**:
Where the **teacher** abides, **briers and thorns** grow—
After great **military campaigns**, **harsh years** must follow.
Thus, the **fruit of virtue** is **simplicity** alone—
One **dares not** use it for **coercion**.
**Simple** yet **not arrogant**,
**Simple** yet **not boastful**,
**Simple** yet **not forced**,
**Simple** yet **not coercive**—
When things **flourish**, they **age**—
This is called **not the Dao/Way**,
And **not the Dao/Way** will **soon perish**.

In the **highest antiquity**,
Each ruled their own **state**,
Each **remembered their people**—
**Harmonious and bright** (*熙熙皞皞*),
They **shared** in **Heaven’s peaceful order** without **affairs**;
**Self and others** were **forgotten in unity**,
**Boundaries dissolved**—
How could there be **warfare** then?

When **shared labor** led to **disorder** and **conquests** began,
**Chiyou** (*蚩尤*) **transgressed** and **arms** were **raised**.
Then, **civilized governance** had **jade and silk**,
**Martial governance** had **weapons and armor**—
**Order** was maintained through **ritual and music**,
**Chaos** was suppressed through **dry weapons and blades**—
Thus, **courts** must **balance civil and martial** **virtue/power** together.»

The **true yang** will naturally arise—

chunks.original_text: 然有道之君子，达而在上，辅佐熙朝，赞襄郅治，惟以道事人主，不以兵强天下。 此是何故？ 盖杀人之父兄，人亦杀其父兄。 人心思返，天道好还。 冤仇报复，靡有休止。 又况兵过之乡，人民罹害； 师行之处，鸡犬亦空。 以故杀戳重而死亡多，尸填巨港，血满长城，无贵无贱，同为枯骨。 生之数不啻杀之数，死之人多于生之人。 由是井里萧条，田野荒废，而荆棘生焉。 且肃杀之气，大伤太和； 乖戾之风，上干天怒。 因而阴阳不燮，雨旸不时，旱干水溢，频来凶荒，饥谨荐至，民不聊生，朝不及夕。 古云大军之后，必有凶年，势所必至也。 然而饥寒交迫，盗心日生； 年岁凶荒，乱民迭作——亦有不得不为兵戎之诘者。 古云“兵贵神速，不贵迟疑”，故善用兵者，亦果而已矣。 行仁义之师，望若时雨； 解倒悬之苦，迎以壶浆。 如武王一戎衣而天下定，无非我武维扬，歼厥渠魁已耳。 何敢逞杀戮于片时，取强威于一己！ 其果而胜也，切勿自矜，矜则有好兵之念； 切勿自伐，自伐有默武之心。 就令除强暴于反掌，登人民于春台，亦安邦定国之常、救世扶危之道，为将帅者分所应尔，何足骄于人哉！ 夫骄人者好杀人者。 纵使果敢弥乱，出斯民于水火，然有三心，虽无杀人之事，而杀人之机已伏于中，非道也。 须知行兵之事，圣人不得已而用之，即未损一兵，未折一将，不伤一民，不戕一物，亦未足语承平之雅观。 何况非圣王所斯许者，果而勿强焉可也。 《诗》云：“劝君莫觅封候事，一将功成万骨枯。 ”以此思之，兵危事，战凶机，非天下生生之道也。 况乎主宾相敌，旷日持久，师老财殚，臣离民怨。 可已而不已，其何以为国乎？ 更有坚壁相持，连年转饷，一旦偶疏，而敌或扼其险要，绝其粮饷——士闻风而预走，军望气以先逃，昔日雄师，今成灰烬，亦何怪其然耶？ 夫亦曰物壮则老，其势有必然者。 且夫用兵之事，以有道诛无道者也。 如此喜兵好战，欲安民反致害民，欲弭乱反将生乱，不道极矣。 夫诛无道而自行不道，何如屯田防寇，休兵睦邻，早已之为愈也。 否则如舜伐三苗，苗民负固，舜不修戎而修德，舞干羽于两阶，七旬而有苗格。 此不威之威，不武之武，胜于威武者多矣，为上者知之否？ 此言用火、行符、采取、烹炼之道，是有为有作。 比用兵克敌，大是一场凶事，不可大意作去。 如曾子之战竞自惕，子思之戒谨时严，方可变化气质之躯，复还先天面目。 若童贞之休，未经凿破，未曾损坏者，固可相时而动，遵道而行，无偏无党，无险无危，直致神化之域。 如破漏之人与年老之体，后天铅汞将尽，性命何依？ 不得不用敲竹唤龟、鼓琴招凤二法，而后有玉芝灵苗，刀圭上药，可采可炼，化凡躯于乌有，结圣胎于灵关。 第火候至密，非得真师口传，万不能洞彻精微； 即得秘密天机，然内德外功，一有不满，犹为神天所不佑。 惟虚心访道，积德累功； 事事无愧，在在怀仁； 以谦以柔，以忍以下； 神依于气，气恋夫神； 绵绵不绝，造到固蒂深根。 决不时而忘之，纷纷驰逐； 时而忆之，切切不已。
chunks.translated_text:
The **virtuous** sovereign of the **Dao/Way**, enlightened and in high station,
Assisted the flourishing court, aiding in **harmonious governance**,
Serving the sovereign with **Dao/Way** alone, never enforcing strength upon the world.

Why is this so?
For he who slays another’s father and brother,
Another will slay his father and brother in return.
Human hearts yearn to return to **harmony**,
**Heaven’s order** favors restoration.
Grievances and vengeance know no end.

Moreover, where armies pass,
The people suffer harm;
Where troops march,
Even chickens and dogs are left desolate.
Thus, slaughter and death multiply—
Corpses fill great rivers, blood stains long walls,
From noble to common, all become dry bones.
The number of those who die exceeds those who live.
Wells grow desolate, fields lie fallow, and brambles take root.

Furthermore, the **killing qi** severely injures **Great Harmony** (*太和*),
The **perverse and rebellious winds** provoke **Heaven’s wrath**.
Thus, **yin-yang** fails to harmonize,
Rain and sun lose their proper time—
Droughts and floods come in succession, calamities follow,
Famine and hardship press upon the people,
Life is not worth a morning or an evening.
The ancients said: *"After a great army, there will surely be a year of famine,"*
A fate that must come to pass.

Yet when hunger and cold press hard,
Banditry grows daily;
When years are barren and calamitous,
Rebellious crowds rise—
Sometimes, war cannot be avoided.
The ancients said: *"Warfare values swiftness, not hesitation,"*
Thus, those skilled in war act decisively.
A **ren-yi** army arrives like timely rain,
Relieving those in dire straits with welcome offerings.
As when **King Wu** in a single campaign pacified the realm,
His purpose was merely to uphold **Dao/Way** and destroy the tyrant’s leader—
How dare he indulge in slaughter for a moment’s gain,
Or seize strength for personal glory!
If victory comes, do not boast—
Boasting breeds a love of war;
Do not self-praise—
Self-praise harbors martial arrogance.
Even if he subdues tyrants with ease,
Elevates the people to prosperity,
This is but the duty of a general to stabilize the state,
To save the world and rescue the endangered—
What cause is there for pride?

For the proud love to kill.
Even if boldness leads to chaos,
Plunging the people into fire and water,
Yet if the heart harbors threefold deceit,
Though no killing occurs, the seed of slaughter lies within—
This is not the **Dao/Way**.

Know this: war is a last resort for the sage,
Even if no soldiers are lost, no generals fallen,
No civilians harmed, no creatures slain,
It is still not the path of lasting peace.
How much less so for those unworthy of the sage’s approval?
Thus, if war must be waged, let it be without excess.

The *Odes* say:
*"Exhort the ruler not to seek the path of feudal lords,
For every general’s triumph rests on ten thousand bones."*

Reflect on this: war is perilous, battle is a dire omen,
Not the **Dao/Way** of nurturing life.

What of prolonged hostilities, where guest and host clash,
Dragging on endlessly, exhausting troops and treasury,
Alienating subjects and inciting grievance?
If it can be stopped but is not, how can it benefit the state?

Or when armies face entrenched defenses,
Years pass in supply lines,
A single moment of negligence—
The enemy seizes the pass,
Cuts off provisions—
Soldiers flee at the first rumor,
Troops scatter at the first sign,
Once mighty forces now reduced to ashes—
What wonder is there in this?
For *"when things reach their peak, they grow old,"*
Such is the inevitable course.

War is used to punish the **Dao/Way**-less with **Dao/Way**.
Yet if one delights in war and strife,
Claiming to pacify the people only to harm them,
To suppress rebellion only to breed it—
This is the ultimate **non-Dao/Way**.

To punish the **Dao/Way**-less while acting without **Dao/Way**—
How is this better than cultivating fields to repel bandits,
Resting arms and fostering goodwill among neighbors?
Early prevention is far superior.

As when **Shun** subdued the **Three Miao**—
The Miao people resisted stubbornly,
Yet Shun did not rely on arms but on **virtue/power**,
Dancing the *Ganyu* at the hall’s steps,
And in seventy days, the Miao submitted in harmony.
This was **威** without coercion, **武** without force—
Far surpassing mere coercion and arms.
Do those in high station know this?

This speaks of the **Dao/Way** of **fire-refinement**,
Of **symbolic talismans**, **gathering**, and **alchemical transformation**—
All deliberate action.
Compared to waging war and defeating the enemy,
This is a far graver matter, not to be taken lightly.

As when **Zengzi** tempered himself in battle,
Or **Zisi** warned of strict discipline in war—
Only thus can one transform **qi** and **spirit**,
Restoring the original, pristine state.
Like the unbroken purity of youth,
Unbroken, unharmed,
One may act in accordance with the times,
Follow the **Dao/Way** without partiality,
Free from peril or danger,
Ascending to the realm of **spiritual transformation**.

But for those already broken or aged,
When **post-heaven** lead and mercury are exhausted,
Where does life depend?
Then must one resort to **enchanting the tortoise** or **summoning the phoenix**—
Striking the bamboo flute, plucking the zither—
Only then may **immortal herbs** and **elixir plants** be gathered,
**Swords of jade** and **alchemical medicines** refined,
Transforming the mortal body into nothingness,
Nurturing the **sacred embryo** at the **spiritual pass**.

Yet the **fire-alchemy** requires the utmost secrecy—
Without a true master’s oral transmission,
One cannot penetrate its deepest mysteries.
Even if the **heavenly secrets** are obtained,
If inner **virtue/power** and outer cultivation are lacking,
Still, the **spirits and **Heaven** will not favor them.

Only with a **empty heart** seeking the **Dao/Way**,
Accumulating **virtue/power** and refining **function**,
In all things without guilt,
In all places embracing **ren**,
With **humility** and **gentleness**,
With **patience** and **yielding**—
**Spirit** abides in **qi**,
**Qi** clings to **spirit**,
Unbroken, ever-flowing,
Rooted in the deepest **primordial foundation**.

Never to be forgotten in haste,
Never to be abandoned in distraction—
At times remembered with urgency,
Never to cease.

chunks.original_text: 故曰：“以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下。 ”即使尽善，而火煅之后，凡气已除，真气未曾积累，势必似无似有，微而难测。 且有不炼而气散，愈炼而气愈散者，皆由心有出入，似蔓草之难除。 故曰：“师之所至，荆棘生焉。 ”况乎神火一煅，阴气难留，而多年之残疾，自幼之沉疴，悉被驱逼——其轻者或从汗液浊溺而出，其重者或外生疮毒而化，种种不一。 修士不可惊为病也，只要心安即能化气。 可见炼己之道，必化凡体为玉体，变浊躯为金躯。 切不可惊，惊则又动后天凡火，而大伤元气也。 故曰：“大军之后，必有凶年。 ”善用兵者贵果敢，善用火者贵神速。 故曰：“果而已矣。 ”在修士当此体化纯乾之时，切不可恃； 恃其才以为不饥不渴，可以行步如飞，冬不炉夏不扇，无端妙用，迥异常人，而自以为强也。 自谓为强，又动后天凡火，不遭外人诽谤，必至内药倾危。 况生一自强之心，即令十月怀胎，三年乳哺，件件功成告毕，不差时刻，而自矜自伐，骄傲凌人，殊非载道之器。 纵果于成功，亦必果于债事。 倾倒之患，安可胜言哉！ 又况自恃其强，而不知谦下存心，虽与修德凝道，犹草木之坚强者无生气，反不敌柔脆者有生机。 势必日复一日、年复一年，光阴愈迈，精气愈衰，欲其长享生人之乐得乎？ 故曰：“物壮则老。 ”以此言之，自高者适以自下，自豪者适以自危，不道甚矣！ 不如去其刚强之心，平平常常，安安稳稳，认理行将去，随天摆布来，庶几不强而自强，不道而有道耶？ 此下手用火之功，大有危险存焉，学者其慎之。 第三十一章 恬淡为上 夫兵者不祥之器，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之，恬淡为上。 胜而不美，而美之者，是乐杀人也。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志于天下矣。 故吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 是以偏将军处左，上将军处右，以丧礼处之。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之； 战胜，以丧礼处之。 圣人之治天下也，道德为上，政教次之。 至不得已而兴征伐之师，备干戈之用，长子师师，弟子舆尸。 为贞为凶，《易》所深戒也。 又况逞虎视之雄，奋鹰扬之烈，耀兵革于疆场，肆威武于兵鄙，以侵伐为利用，以争战为能事者乎？ 如此用兵，非弥乱也，实佳兵也。 夫佳兵者，不祥之器。 古人以止戈为武，此则以穷兵为能，非君常用之器也。 君子常用之器为何？ 道也，德也，好生恶杀也。 若言兵则杀机见矣。 夫杀伐声张，河山震动，虽鸡犬为之不安，惨何极乎？ 况蚯蚓尚且贪生，蝼蚁亦知畏死，物之至微至蠢者，犹深恶之，何论人乎？ 是以有道之士，不屑处也。 凡物贵阳而贱阴——左为阳，生气也； 右为阴，杀机也。 是以君子之居，平常尚左，独至用兵之际，不尚左而尚右，其贱兵可知矣！ 就令除残去暴，伐罪吊民，悬正正之旗，布堂堂之阵，要属不祥之器，圣王所不乐耳。 夫国家承平，固无需乎武备。 一旦边陲告急，叛乱频生，万不得已而用兵，亦惟是步伍整齐，赏罚严肃。 凡师行之处，乐供壶浆； 兵过之乡，仍安耕凿。 所谓克柔克刚，以威以德者，于此可验矣。 不逞兵威，不夸将略，惟是恬淡无为，从容自得。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus it is said: *"Those who aid the sovereign with the Dao/Way do not rely on arms to subdue the world."* Even if one attains perfect refinement, yet after the fire-alchemical tempering, when all coarse *qi* has been purged and true *qi* has yet to accumulate, the result will be indeterminate—neither fully present nor fully absent, subtle and difficult to discern. Moreover, there are those who, without cultivation, scatter their *qi*, and the more they refine, the more their *qi* disperses—all due to the mind’s restless fluctuations, like creeping vines that resist eradication. Hence it is said: *"Where the master treads, brambles spring up."* How much more so when the divine fire is applied, for yin *qi* resists retention, and long-standing ailments or childhood infirmities are driven forth—some exiting through sweat, turbid urine, or waste, while others manifest as external sores or toxins, varying in form. The cultivator must not mistake these for illness; only a tranquil mind can transmute *qi*.

Thus, the Dao of self-cultivation must transform the common body into a jade-like one, the turbid form into a golden one. Never be alarmed—for alarm stirs the posterior-heaven’s vulgar fire and gravely injures the primordial *qi*. Hence it is said: *"After a great campaign, there will surely be years of calamity."* Those skilled in warfare value decisiveness; those skilled in fire-alchemy value swiftness and subtlety. Hence it is said: *"Decisive and complete."* When the cultivator reaches the stage of pure *yang* transformation, they must not rely on their attainment, supposing themselves unfettered by hunger or thirst, able to move like the wind, requiring no stove in winter or fan in summer, displaying marvelous feats beyond ordinary men, and thus deeming themselves strong. To boast of such strength is to again agitate the posterior-heaven’s vulgar fire; if not met with external censure, the internal elixir will surely falter. Worse still, if one harbors a self-aggrandizing spirit—even if they complete ten months of gestation and three years of nurturing, fulfilling every task with precision, yet still pride themselves and boast, arrogantly overbearing others—they are far from the vessel of the Dao. Even if successful in their endeavors, they will surely meet ruin in their debts. The peril of collapse is beyond reckoning!

What then of those who, relying on their strength, fail to cultivate humility and sincerity? Though they may practice virtue and concentrate on the Dao, they remain like rigid trees—strong yet lifeless—while the supple and fragile retain vitality. Day by day, year by year, as time passes, their vital essence wanes. How could they long enjoy the joys of mortal life? Hence it is said: *"When things are at their peak, decay begins."* By this reasoning, those who exalt themselves only bring themselves low; those who boast invite peril. How un-Dao!

Better to discard the rigid heart, maintaining simplicity and steadiness, adhering to principle while letting go of contrivance, yielding to Heaven’s arrangement—thus achieving strength without force, the Dao without effort. Here lies the peril of the initial fire-alchemical stages; let the scholar beware.

---
**Chapter Thirty-One: Tranquility and Simplicity as Supreme**

Warfare is an inauspicious instrument; men detest it, and thus those who follow the Dao avoid it. The noble man, at home, values the left; in war, the right. Warfare is an inauspicious instrument, not the tool of the noble. Used only when unavoidable, tranquility and simplicity are paramount. To triumph yet take no pleasure in it—those who do are but lovers of killing. He who delights in killing cannot prevail under Heaven.

Thus, auspicious matters are honored on the left; inauspicious on the right. Hence the left general is stationed left, the right general right, and funeral rites are observed. Many lives lost are mourned with tears; victory is treated with funeral solemnity. The sage governs Heaven and Earth with virtue and morality as supreme, law and teaching secondary. Only when forced to raise armies, wield arms, and send eldest sons to war—where younger sons bear the dead—does the *Yijing* warn: *"This is ominous, this is perilous."*

How much worse for those who revel in the tiger’s gaze, the eagle’s fierceness, who display arms on the battlefield and wield might in the barracks, who see conquest as gain and warfare as skill! Such warfare is not merely chaotic—it is the finest of arms. For the finest arms are inauspicious instruments. The ancients called halting the blade *wu* (martial virtue); these men call exhausting warfare skill—hardly the tool of the sage.

The noble’s true instruments are the Dao, virtue, and the love of life while abhorring death. To speak of arms is to speak of slaughter. When the sounds of killing resound and the land trembles, even chickens and dogs are unsettled—what then of the horror inflicted? Even earthworms cling to life, ants fear death; the most insignificant creatures recoil. How much more so for men? Thus, those who follow the Dao avoid such places.

All things value *yang* over *yin*—the left is *yang*, the breath of life; the right is *yin*, the seed of slaughter. Hence the noble, in ordinary times, honors the left. Only in war does he abandon the left for the right, revealing how little he esteems arms.

Even if one eliminates tyrants, punishes the wicked, and raises righteous banners in orderly ranks, warfare remains an inauspicious instrument, one the sage avoids. In times of peace, a state needs no martial preparations. When borders cry out in alarm and rebellions flare, and only then must arms be raised, the discipline must be strict, rewards and punishments unyielding. Where the army passes, the people offer wine and grain; where the soldiers march, the fields remain undisturbed. Thus does one conquer the rigid with flexibility, the fierce with virtue—evident in such conduct.

Let there be no display of martial might, no boasting of strategy. Only tranquility and non-action, ease and naturalness, suffice.

chunks.original_text: 虽处戎马纷争之地，俨具步伍安祥之风。 以此取城，何城不克？ 以此制敌，何敌不摧？ 其胜有必然者。 虽然，其胜也亦兵家之常，乌得谓钟鼎铭勋，旗裳纪绩？ 遂以此为后世美观乎？ 倘以此为美观，是必忍万姓之荼毒，博一己之功名。 无生人之德，而有杀人之心，亦奚可哉？ 夫乐杀人者，其心残忍，其法森严，不能大度以容人，常苛刻而自是。 斯人也不可得志于天下。 如得志于天下，苍生无遗类矣。 古者吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 彼偏将军，将之次也，反居其左； 上将军，将之上也，转居其右。 亦知专杀伐之权者为上将军，偏将必禀命于其上，不得逞杀伐之威，是亦丧礼处军礼矣。 夫岂若国书对垒，命士卒咸歌送葬之词也哉？ 岂谨慎小心之至也。 又曰“杀人众多，以悲哀泣之”者何？ 明战伐之事，伤彼苍好生之心，实出于无可奈何！ 故吊古战场者，睹此尸满城濠，血盈沟壑，天地一若含悲，草木一若生愁，而况人乎？ 即使战而胜，群酋率服，万姓又安，而反己思维，觉宇下苍苍赤子，遭锋镝而流离者半，死亡者亦半，心滋戚矣！ 何敢以奏凯还朝，歌功颂德而自炫其才能耶？ 念及此而毫无德色，反多戚容，仍以丧礼处之而已矣。 孟子曰：“我善为阵，我善为战，大罪也； 惟国君好仁，天下无敌也。 ”又曰：“威天下不以兵革之利。 ”足见神武不杀，仁者无敌，允为治世之良模，而用兵非圣人之常道，王者所不贵也 此喻临炉用火，实为老弱之人，扶衰救弊，不得已而为之，何敢矜奇立异，自诩为功耶？ 彼旁门左道，以进火退符、采药炼丹，一切有作有为之法，视为神仙之道，误矣，远矣！ 然少壮之全，不须采炼之工，可以得药结丹，而衰老之躯，气质物欲，濡染已久，不加猛烹急炼之功，则气质不化，物欲难除。 以污浊之身，而欲行无为自然之道，安可得乎？ 是犹屋子不洁，嘉宾难迎。 人须扫除身中污垢，而后色相俱空，尘根悉拔，本来真性，自在个中。 虽然勉强修持，亦要安然自在，方不动后天凡火，有伤性命。 故太上以恬淡为上，胜而不美。 否则有后天而无先天，仅凡气而无真气。 一腔火性，其能久耶？ 故曰美之者，是以杀人为乐也。 以杀人为乐，则杀机满腹，乌足为天下之主，受天下之福？ 其不可得志于天下也必矣。 是知修炼之士，虽用作为工夫，亦要有仁慈恻怛之怀，谦下柔和之心，斯后天中方有先天。 古人火候无爻策，药物无斤两，顺天而动，率性而行。 虽有作为，亦不为害也。 第三十二章 知止不殆 道常无名。 朴虽小，天下不敢臣。 侯王若能守，万物将自宾。 天地相合，以降甘露，人莫之令而自均。 始制有名，名亦既有，夫亦将知止； 知止所以不殆。 譬道之在天下，犹川谷之于江海也。 道本冲漠无朕，而实万象森列，无人不具，无物不有。 人物未生以前，此物实为之本。 人物既生以后，此物又为之根。 虽至隐至微，而要不可一刻离也； 离则万事万物皆瓦裂矣。 故曰“道常无名”。 为学人计，不得不为之名。 曰黍珠一粒，阳神三寸，自在玄宫，周通法界，犹之太朴完全。 其物虽小，其用则大。 天下万事万物，俱赖此以为君，孰得臣而后之耶？ 即如侯王操生杀之权，为万民之主，孰敢不奉其命令？

Though stationed amid the tumult of war, yet maintaining the orderly and tranquil demeanor of disciplined ranks.
With this approach, what fortress cannot be taken?
With this approach, what enemy cannot be crushed?
Its victory is inevitable.

Yet even so, such victory is but the common fate of arms—how dare one carve triumphs upon bronze and stone, or record exploits upon banners and scrolls, and thus claim eternal renown for posterity?
If such renown is sought, then one must endure the suffering of countless lives to achieve a single man’s glory.
To lack the virtue of nurturing life while harboring the intent to take it—how can this be justified?

He who delights in killing is cruel of heart, his laws harsh and unyielding.
He cannot embrace breadth to contain others, ever petty and self-righteous.
Such a man cannot prevail in the world.
If he were to prevail, the common folk would be utterly destroyed.

In ancient times, auspicious matters were observed on the left, inauspicious on the right.
Yet the *piān jiāngjūn* (偏将军), a subordinate commander, is placed on the left—
while the *shàng jiāngjūn* (上将军), the supreme commander, is stationed on the right.
For the supreme commander wields the authority of slaughter, while subordinate generals must obey his orders and cannot flaunt their martial might—
this is but the military equivalent of funeral rites.

How much more refined than opposing armies with national decrees,
commanding soldiers to sing dirges as if escorting the dead!
How meticulous and reverent!

And what of the saying, *"When many are slain, weep with sorrow"*?
It is clear that warfare wounds the natural compassion for life,
and arises only from dire necessity.
Thus, those who mourn ancient battlefields see corpses filling the moats,
blood swelling the ravines—
the heavens and earth seem to weep,
the grasses and trees to sigh,
and what of mortal men?
Even if war is won, the chieftains submit,
the people find peace—
yet reflecting inwardly,
one sees beneath the heavens countless children
scattered by blade and arrow,
half exiled, half dead—
and the heart is filled with grief!
How dare one return in triumph,
singing praises of valor,
and boast of one’s prowess?

To ponder this and yet show no remorse,
but instead wear a mournful countenance,
treating it as a funeral rite—
this is the way.

Mencius said:
*"If I excel in arraying troops and waging war, this is a great sin.
Only when the sovereign loves virtue does the world have no rival."*
And again:
*"One does not subdue the world through the advantage of arms."*

This proves that the martial and mighty do not kill,
and the virtuous are unconquerable—
truly the ideal for an age of peace,
while warfare is not the constant path of the sage,
nor the ambition of the king.

This is like using fire at the furnace—
an act of necessity for the weak and infirm,
to revive decay and mend what is broken.
How dare one boast of cleverness or novelty,
and claim such deeds as merit?

Those who follow false paths—
retreat and advance with talismans,
gather herbs and refine elixirs,
all contrived methods of action—
mistakenly believe them the Dao of immortals.
They err greatly.

Yet for the vigorous and young,
no need for such alchemical labor—
one may attain the elixir naturally.
But for the aged and debilitated,
whose vital essence and desires have long been corrupted,
without fierce refining and urgent transformation,
the essence remains unrefined,
desires unchecked.
With a polluted body,
how can one practice the Way of effortless spontaneity?

It is like welcoming honored guests in a filthy house—
impossible.
One must first purge the defilements within,
until form and perception dissolve,
the dust of attachment is uprooted,
and the original true nature manifests freely.

Even if one strives in cultivation,
one must remain at ease and unconstrained,
lest artificial fire harm the innate.
Thus, the highest sage values tranquility above all,
and victory without vanity.

Otherwise, there is only the artificial without the natural,
mere common *qi* without true *qi*.
A single flame of passion—
how long can it endure?
Thus it is said:
*"To glorify such things is to delight in killing."*

To delight in killing is to harbor slaughter in one’s heart—
how can such a man govern the world
and receive its blessings?
His failure to prevail is certain.

Thus, those who cultivate must,
though they act,
nurture a heart of compassion and pity,
a mind of humility and gentleness—
only then does the artificial contain the natural.

The ancients adjusted their methods without rigid formulas,
measured their medicines without precise weights,
acting in harmony with Heaven,
following their true nature.
Though they acted,
they did no harm.

---
**Chapter Thirty-Two: Knowing When to Stop Brings No Peril**

The Dao is ever nameless.
Though crude simplicity is small,
the world dares not submit to it.
If lords and kings could guard it,
all things would come of their own accord.

Heaven and Earth unite,
and sweet dew descends—
no one commands it,
yet all is evenly nourished.

When names first arose,
and names were established,
then one must know when to stop—
knowing when to stop brings no peril.

Compare the Dao in the world
to rivers and valleys flowing into the sea.
The Dao is originally boundless and formless,
yet all phenomena arise within it—
present in all beings,
inherent in all things.
Before humans existed,
this was their origin.
After humans emerged,
this remains their root.
Though subtle and hidden,
it cannot for an instant be separated—
for if it were, all things would shatter.

Thus it is said:
*"The Dao is ever nameless."*

For those who seek the Way,
names must be given.
A grain of millet, three inches of yang spirit—
dwelling in the mysterious palace,
pervading the Dharma realm—
just as the Original Simplicity is whole.
Though small in form,
its function is vast.
All things in the world rely on it as sovereign—
who would dare to be its subject?

Even as lords and kings hold the power of life and death,
and rule over the people,
who would dare not obey their commands?

The person who attains this Original Simplicity,
with unwavering reverence,
holds fast and never loses it—
though lands and realms may differ,
none would fail to cross seas and scale mountains to come,
let alone those nearby.

Thus it is seen:
All under the heavens submit in homage,
all due to the power of this Original Simplicity to preserve.

Yet once humans are born,
their **qi** and nature constrain them,
desires cloud them—
few retain the Dao in its entirety.

If one seeks to embrace Original Simplicity and remain whole and pure,
only by imitating the heavens and earth can this be done.

The **qi** of heaven descends,
the **qi** of earth ascends—
just as in humans, the **Kan** and **Li** energies intermingle,
water and fire in harmony.

When heaven and earth unite,
sweet dew descends like pearls,
naturally falling into the **Zhong Gong**—
this is the **Yin-Yang** balancing,
the **sun and moon** sharing the same palace—
who commands it?
Who directs it?

All arises from the Dao as sovereign.
Yet what name does the Dao truly have?

Some say *"True Lead"* (真鉛),
others say *"Golden Elixir"* (金丹).
The ancients coined these names
only for the sake of later cultivators.

Once cultivators know its name,
they must then seek its reality.

chunks.original_text: 彼自阴阳交媾，一点落于黄庭，就当止其所而不迁，安其居而不动，斯大道乃常存也。 既知所止，中有主而不易，又奚至生灭而遭危殆之辱耶？ 可见道散于外，浩渺无垠，浑沦莫测。 及敛之于内，混混沌沌，退藏有密。 学者苟莫知统宗，无从归宿，则散而无纪，即立己犹不能，焉能及人？ 故曰：“道之在天下，犹川谷之于江海。 ”惟有主归，所以成其大也。 子思谓君子之道费而隐，其即此一本散万殊，万殊归一本之道也。 此章甘露是铅汞合而始降，“知止”是神气萃于中宫。 太上俱浑言之，吾再详道之：学人欲修性命，先明铅汞。 古云：汞是我家固有之物，铅乃他家不死之方。 若但言心性，无从捉摸，古仙真借名为汞。 此个汞非他，乃心中灵液——从涕唾津精气血液，后天所生阴滓物中，加以神火下照久久，化为至灵之液。 此个灵液，元性所寄。 盖以本性原来清净，不染纤尘，与太空等。 非从后天色身所有之精，用起文武火，加以神光了照，则灵液不化，灵性无依。 故炼丹之士，必先炼精化气，所谓“此精不是凡人精，乃是玉皇口内涎。 ”玉皇比心也，心中灵液即涎也。 既得精生汞化，由是灵液下降坎宫，真阳亦复上升，交会于黄庭内釜，我以神气凝注于此，久之真铅从此蓬勃絪缊而有象，此即所谓“得药”也。 然灵液取真水也，真阳即真气，真气即铅也。 汞为精、铅为凡，二者皆后天有形有象之铅汞，只可顺而生男育女，不可为长生大药。 必从此汞之下降，铅之上升，会合中宫，凝神调息，片刻间兀兀腾腾，如雾及烟，如潮如海，才算是真铅，可为炼丹之本，所谓坎离交而得药也。 于是运起阳火阴符，逆从尾闾直上泥丸。 泥丸久积阴精，与我这点真铅之气，配合为一，即所谓“乾坤交而结丹”是也。 阳气上升泥丸，有何景象？ 觉得头目爽利，非等平日之昏晕，有如风吹云散，而天朗气清，另有一番气象，才算是真汞。 以前之汞，还是凡汞，不可以养成仙胎。 铅汞会于泥丸，斯时之凡精凡气，合同而化，不见有铅，并不见有汞，是一清凉恬淡之味，化为甘露神水，香甜可口，不似平日粗精浊气，即古人谓“醍醐灌顶”是。 从上腭落下，吞而服之，遂入黄庭温养，即封固矣。 此个真精一生，浑身苏软如绵，欲睡不睡，欲醒不醒； 而平日动荡之身心，至此浑然湛然，不动不摇，自安所止而得所止，又有何殆之有哉？ 此境非大静大定不能。 若夫采取之法，即一意凝注，毫不分散，古人谓之“不采之采胜于采”是。 学人行一步自有一步之效验。 若无真实处，工犹未至。 天机毕露，人其自取证焉可。 第三十三章 知人者智 智人者智，自知者明。 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 知足者富，强行者有志。 不失其所者久，死而不亡者寿。 修身之道，不外性命。 人欲尽性立命，必先存心养性，保命全形。 予以修之炼之，积之累之，则本性长圆，天命在我矣。 然欲尽心，必先知性，知得人生之本，纯乎天理，不杂人欲，谓之睿智。 由此遏欲存理，时时省察，刻刻防闲，务令私欲尽净，天理流行，洞见本来面目，惺惺不昧，了了常明，即是圆明妙觉。 此非外面想像，乃自家真知，他人莫能喻也。 故曰“知人者智，自知者明”。
chunks.translated_text:
「From the very moment the **Yin-Yang** energies intermingle,
a single point settles within the **Yellow Court** (黃庭).
Then one must cease its movement and remain steadfast,
settle its dwelling and remain unshaken—
thus the **Great Dao** endures perpetually.

Having known where to halt,
there is an inherent master that does not change,
so why would it suffer the humiliation of birth and death?

Thus, it is seen that the Dao disperses outward,
vast and boundless, unfathomable and indistinct.
When gathered inward,
it becomes indistinct and chaotic,
retiring and concealing itself in profound mystery.

If scholars do not grasp the **root principle** (統宗),
they lack a foundation to return to,
and thus scatter without measure.
Even establishing oneself proves impossible,
how then could one reach others?

Hence it is said:
*"The Dao in the world is like rivers and valleys to the ocean."*

Only by attaining the **root principle** does one achieve greatness.

Zi Si (子思) spoke of the **Way** of the **Junzi** (君子) as costly yet hidden—
this is the **one source** giving rise to myriad transformations,
where myriad transformations return to the **one source** of the **Way**.

In this chapter, the **sweet dew** (甘露) is the **True Lead** (**Kan**) and **True Mercury** (**Li**) merging before descending.
**"Knowing the halt"** (知止) is the **divine qi** gathering in the **Yellow Court** (中宫).

The **Taoist Canon** (太上) speaks of **perfect unity** (俱浑),
but I shall elaborate further:
Those who wish to cultivate **life and death** (性命),
must first clarify **True Lead** and **True Mercury**.

The ancients said:
*"Mercury is the inherent substance of my family,
Lead is the elixir of immortality from another."*

If one speaks only of **heart-nature** (心性),
there is no way to grasp it,
so the ancient **true immortals** (真仙) and **true ones** (真人) borrowed the name **Mercury**.

This **Mercury** is not the other—
it is the **heart’s essence**, the **soul’s elixir**—
borne from **nasal mucus, saliva, seminal fluid, vital essences, blood, and fluids**,
from the **postnatal turbid residues** (後天阴滓物),
illuminated by **divine fire** (神火) descending for a long time,
refined into the most **sublime essence**.

This **sublime essence** is the **host of original nature** (元性所寄).
For **original nature** is inherently pure and clear,
untainted by the slightest dust,
equal to the **Great Void**.

It is not the **postnatal essence** (後天之精) of the physical body,
nor the **vital breath** (氣) produced by **civilized and martial fires** (文武火),
nor the **divine light** (神光) that illuminates it—
otherwise, the **sublime essence** would not refine,
and the **sublime nature** would lack its foundation.

Thus, those who forge the **elixir** (丹),
must first **refine essence into breath** (炼精化气),
as said:
*"This essence is not the common man’s essence,
but the **Jade Emperor’s** (玉皇) saliva from within his mouth."*

The **Jade Emperor** is likened to the **heart**,
and this **sublime essence** is the **saliva**.

Once **essence is refined into Mercury** (精生汞化),
the **sublime essence** descends into the **Kan palace** (坎宫),
and the **True Yang** (真陽) ascends as well,
uniting within the **Yellow Court’s** (黃庭) **inner cauldron** (內釜).
I condense my **divine qi** (神气) here,
and over time, **True Lead** emerges, flourishing and manifesting—
this is what is called **"obtaining the medicine"** (得藥).

Yet the **sublime essence** is **True Water** (真水),
and the **True Yang** is **True Qi** (真氣),
**True Qi** being **True Lead** (鉛).

**Mercury** is **essence**,
**Lead** is **common**—
both are **postnatal substances** (後天) with form and appearance,
capable only of **nurturing vitality** (順而生男育女),
not of **eternal life’s** great medicine.

Only when **Mercury** descends and **Lead** ascends,
uniting in the **Yellow Court**,
condensing **divine qi** and regulating **breath**,
does one feel, in an instant,
a **boiling, surging** sensation—
like mist and smoke,
like tides and waves—
then does it become **True Lead**,
worthy as the foundation for **elixir forging** (炼丹之本),
as said:
*"Kan and Li unite to obtain the medicine."*

Then, **Yang fire** (陽火) and **Yin elixir** (陰符) are stirred,
ascending from the **tail vein** (尾闾) to the **muddy pellet** (泥丸).
The **muddy pellet**, long storing **Yin essence** (陰精),
combines with this **True Lead qi** (真鉛之氣),
forming a single entity—
this is what is called:
*"**Qian and Kun** unite to forge the **elixir** (結丹)."*

When **Yang qi** ascends to the **muddy pellet**,
what manifestation does it show?
A **refreshing clarity** in the head and eyes,
unlike the usual **dullness and dizziness**,
as if the wind disperses clouds and the sky clears—
a distinct transformation,
this is **True Mercury**.

The **Mercury** of before was still **common Mercury**,
unfit to nourish the **embryo of immortality** (仙胎).

When **Lead** and **Mercury** meet in the **muddy pellet**,
the **postnatal essence** and **postnatal qi** (凡精凡氣)
merge and transform,
no longer seen as **Lead** or **Mercury**,
but as a **pure, cool, and tranquil** taste—
refined into **sweet dew divine water** (甘露神水),
fragrant and sweet to the palate,
unlike the usual **coarse essence and turbid qi**,
this is what the ancients called:
*"**Amrita** (醍醐) anointing the **crown"** (灌顶).*

Swallowed from the **upper palate** (上腭),
it enters the **Yellow Court** to be **nurtured in warmth** (溫養),
and is then **sealed and secured** (封固).

This **True Essence**, once born,
softens the entire body like silk,
neither sleep nor wakefulness is desired;
while the usual **agitated body and mind** (動蕩之身心)
now rest in **perfect stillness** (浑然湛然),
unmoved and unshaken—
naturally attaining **stillness** (安所止) and **halt** (得所止),
what peril could there be?

This realm requires **Great Stillness and Great Clarity** (大静大定).
If one **harvests** (采取) with **single-minded focus** (一意凝注),
not scattering in the slightest,
the ancients called this:
*"**Non-harvesting harvesting** (不采之采) surpasses harvesting."*

Cultivators advance one step and see one step’s effects.
If there is no **true foundation** (真实处),
the practice remains incomplete.

When **heavenly mechanisms** (天机) are fully revealed,
one may **attain verification** (取证) by oneself.

---
**Chapter Thirty-Three: Knowing Others is Wisdom**
Wisdom in knowing others is wisdom,
self-awareness is clarity.

Overcoming others requires strength,
self-mastery is power.

Contentment brings wealth,
unyielding resolve brings purpose.

Losing nothing ensures longevity,
dying yet not perishing is true life.

The **Way** of cultivating oneself
lies only in **life and death** (性命).
If one seeks to **fulfill nature and establish fate** (尽性立命),
one must first **preserve the heart and nurture nature** (存心养性),
**safeguard life and maintain form** (保命全形).

I **cultivate** and **forge** it,
**accumulate** and **pile** it—
then **original nature** (本性) endures and **heavenly fate** (天命) is mine.

Yet to **fulfill the heart** (尽心),
one must first **know nature** (知性),
to perceive **the foundation of human life** (人生之本),
purely **heavenly principle** (天理),
unmixed with **human desires** (人欲)—
this is called **insightful wisdom** (睿智).

From this, **restraining desire and preserving principle** (遏欲存理),
constantly **self-examining** (省察),
ever **vigilant** (防闲),
ensuring **private desires are utterly purified** (私欲尽净),
**heavenly principle flows freely** (天理流行),
**piercing the original face** (洞见本来面目),
**lucid and unobstructed** (惺惺不昧),
**ever-clear** (了了常明)—
this is **perfect clarity and wondrous awakening** (圆明妙觉).

This is not **external speculation**,
but **one’s own true knowing**—
no other can comprehend it.

Hence it is said:
*"Knowing others is wisdom,
self-awareness is clarity."*
chunks.overlap_context:
When heaven and earth unite,
sweet dew descends like pearls,
naturally falling into the **Zhong Gong**—
this is the **Yin-Yang** balancing,
the **sun and moon** sharing the same palace—
who commands it?
Who directs it?

All arises from the Dao as sovereign.
Yet what name does the Dao truly have?

Some say *"True Lead"* (真鉛),
others say *"Golden Elixir"* (金丹).
The ancients coined these names
only for the sake of later cultivators.

Once cultivators know its name,
they must then seek its reality.

chunks.original_text: 若欲立命，必先炼己。 炼己有两端：一曰物欲——物欲不除，天真难现。 舍此而欲得药结丹，亦犹嘉禾杂荑稗之中，不先芟荑，势必苗莠并植。 非先胜人欲，常操常存，则有定守，未必有定力也。 故曰“胜人者有力。 ”一曰气质——气质不化，身何由固？ 所以剥肤存液，剥液存神，剥神还虚，层层剥尽，方能与道合真。 苟非精固气壮，焉能战胜群阴，扫除六贼，致令一身内外，精莹如玉，变化凡躯，炼成仙体哉？ 故曰“自胜者强”。 如是炼己了矣，命已立矣，功不于此尽乎？ 道不于此成乎？ 虽然，起火有时，止火有候，若当火足之时，不行止火之功，精必随气之动而动，故知止养丹，如贫者之积财而富，常觉有余。 既知止火，尤要进火以养丹，退火以温丹。 非有志之士，断不能绵绵密密，不二之息如此也。 《易》曰：“天行健，君子以自强不息。
chunks.translated_text:
To **establish the vital mandate** (立命),
one must first **refine oneself** (炼己).
Refining oneself has two aspects:
One is **material desires** (物欲)—
if **material desires are not eliminated** (物欲不除),
**heavenly purity will not manifest** (天真难现).
To abandon these and seek **elixir and alchemical immortality** (药结丹) instead
is like a fine grain of millet mixed with weeds and tares—
without first uprooting the weeds (芟荑),
the good and the bad will inevitably grow together (苗莠并植).
Only by first **conquering human desires** (胜人欲),
constantly **maintaining and preserving** (常操常存),
can one achieve **steadfastness in practice** (有定守),
though not necessarily **steadfastness in power** (有定力).
Hence it is said:
*"To conquer others is to have power."*

The second is **constitutional qi** (气质)—
if **constitutional qi is not transformed** (气质不化),
how can the body **become firm** (身何由固)?
Thus, one **peels away the flesh to preserve the fluids** (剥肤存液),
**peels away the fluids to preserve the spirit** (剥液存神),
**peels away the spirit to return to the void** (剥神还虚),
layer by layer, stripping away until
one can **align with the Dao in truth** (与道合真).
If not **qi is robust and spirit is vigorous** (精固气壮),
how could one **vanquish all pathogenic forces** (战胜群阴),
**sweep away the six external evils** (扫除六贼),
so that **one’s inner and outer self becomes luminous as jade** (一身内外，精莹如玉),
**transmutes the mortal form** (变化凡躯),
and **refines into an immortal body** (炼成仙体)?
Hence it is said:
*"To conquer oneself is to grow strong."*

When refining oneself is thus complete (炼己了矣),
the vital mandate is **established** (命已立矣).
Does the **work end here** (功不于此尽乎)?
Does the **Dao reach fulfillment here** (道不于此成乎)?
Though it may seem so,
**igniting the furnace has its time** (起火有时),
**extinguishing the furnace has its moment** (止火有候).
If one does not **practice extinguishing the furnace** (止火之功) when the time is right (火足之时),
the **essence will move with the stirring of qi** (精必随气之动而动),
thus one knows that **stopping to nourish the elixir** (止养丹)
is like a poor man **accumulating wealth until he becomes rich** (积财而富),
**ever-awakened with abundance** (常觉有余).

Having known how to **extinguish the furnace** (止火),
one must also **advance the furnace to nourish the elixir** (进火以养丹),
**retreat the furnace to warm the elixir** (退火以温丹).
Only those with **resolute determination** (有志之士)
can **persistently and meticulously** (绵绵密密)
**inhale and exhale without interruption** (不二之息).
The *Classic of Changes* (《易》) says:
*"Heaven moves with vigor,
the virtuous person **strengthens himself without ceasing** (自强不息)."*
