chunks.original_text: 因物付物，以人治人，即以大小多少投报，亦皆动与天随，头头是道，处处无差，而于己无乖，予人无忤焉。 噫，此道之至难而至易，至大而至细者也。 无如世之修士，计近功速效，往往好为其难，喜务其大，不知图难于易； 细为大之本，故天下大事必作于细。 况道为万事万物之根，可不由易而难，自细而大乎？ 不然进之锐者退必速矣，又安望几于神化之域哉？ 是以古之圣人，知道有由阶、学有由进，不思远大之图，惟期切近之旨，淘汰渣滓，涵养本源，如水之浸灌草木，自然日变月化，不见其长而日长。 所以自微之着，由粗之精，从有为有事中，而至于无为无事； 愈淡愈浓，弥近弥远，而至于美大之诣。 圣人终不为大，故能成其大也。 今之学者，初起下手，便望成仙，心愈大事愈难，竟至半途而废者多矣。 惟有坚固耐烦，矢以恒久不息之心，庶几易者而难者亦易，细者细而大者亦细耳。 愿学者图难于易，为大于细，出以持重老成，不至暴躁浅率得矣。 不然，非但斯道之大，务以敦厚居心始克有得，即此一应诺间，轻于唯者必寡信，而后悔弥深； 一进取内，好易者每多难，而退缩在即。 其事有必然者。 故圣人修炼之始，虽从易从细以为基，而惟日孜孜，其难其慎，此心终未已也。 所以先为其难，而其后顺水推舟，行所无事，故曰“终无难”焉。 此“为无为”三句，是纯任自然工夫。 以下图难于易，是欲造精深必由浅近之意。 至于丹道，言铅言汞，究是何物？ 不妨明辩之：要知此个物事，不外阴阳两端。 以汞配铅，即如以女配男，交媾之后，化生元气出来，又将元气合阴气入中宫，然后成丹。 在先天离是纯阳之乾，坎是纯阴之坤。 因气机一动，乾之中爻走入坤中，坤之中爻走入乾窍，乾遂虚而为离，坤遂实而为坎。 故乾虽阳而有阴，坤虽阴而有阳，即非先纯阴纯阳太极浑沦之旧。 然犹不失真正也。 久之神则生精，气则化血，而质气之性，气数之命，从此出矣。 盖以有思虑知觉之心，气血形体之身，不似乾坤原物。 至人以法追摄离中一点己汞（汞为心液，液虽属阴，却从离火中出，带有火性），下入坎宫，熏坎宫一点阴血（血为坎水，水虽属阳，却从坎水中生，实为寒体）——古人谓“火入水乡”，“神入气里”——犹冰凝之遇火，如炭火之热釜，自然温暖，生出阴蹻一脉动气来。 虽然，火入水中，犹釜底加炭，热气熏蒸，蓬勃上腾，即真铅生也。 自此以神运之，而上升泥丸（主宰之而已），犹烤酒甑中，热气被火而升入天锅，则成露珠滴入瓮中（此即吾教曰“真汞”、又曰“忙将北海初潮水，灌济东山老树根”），其实气化为液而已。 复行归炉温养，液又化气，循环不已，一升一降，直将气血之躯，阴气剥尽，凡身化为金身，浊体变为乾体，仍还我太极虚无，不生不灭之法身焉。 昔朱元育云：“对坎离言，身中离精坎气，皆属凡铅，直到坎离交媾，真阴真阳会合，生出一点真阳出来，才算先天真铅种子。 然未得明师口诀，纵使勉强把持，也只可以固色身，到得下元充壮，久必倾泄矣。 学人得此阳生，只算一边工夫，安望结胎成圣？ 惟将此阳气引之上升，复合周身阴精，更与泥丸绛宫之神髓灵液，交合为一——此正谓“东家女（木汞也），西舍郎（金铅也），配合夫妻入洞房。
chunks.translated_text:
「To treat things by returning them to their nature,
and to govern people by aligning with their own *Dao*,
is to respond with greatness and smallness, abundance and scarcity—
all movements follow the natural order of Heaven,
each action is the *Dao*,
everywhere without distinction,
yet never conflicting with oneself,
nor ever clashing with others.

Ah, this is the *Dao* most difficult yet most simple,
most vast yet most minute.

Yet how many practitioners in the world
seek quick results and immediate gains,
often embracing what is difficult,
and favoring what is grand,
without knowing that difficulty arises from simplicity,
and grandeur stems from the minute.

Thus, all great undertakings in the world
must begin with the small.

Since the *Dao* is the root of all things,
how could one not proceed from ease to difficulty,
from minute to vast?

Otherwise, those who advance too swiftly
shall retreat just as quickly—
how then could they hope to reach the realm of divine transformation?

Therefore, the ancient sages knew
that the *Dao* has stages to traverse,
and learning has steps to ascend,
yet they did not ponder grand schemes,
only striving for the immediate essence.
They refined what was coarse,
nurtured the fundamental source,
like water permeating plants—
naturally changing day by day,
transforming month by month,
not seen to grow yet ever growing.

Thus, from the subtle beginnings,
from the crude to the refined,
they moved from *action* and *doing*
to *non-action* and *actionless action*,
ever more plain yet ever more profound,
ever closer yet ever more distant,
until they attained the realm of supreme beauty.

The sage never seeks the grand,
and thus achieves the grand.

Nowadays, scholars at their outset
aspire to become immortals,
the more ambitious their hearts,
the more difficult their tasks—
and so many falter halfway through.

Only through steadfast endurance,
with unwavering resolve,
can the difficult become easy,
the minute remain minute,
and the grand be made small.

I urge scholars to embrace difficulty in simplicity,
to attain grandeur through the minute,
to proceed with measured caution and maturity,
and thus avoid recklessness and superficiality.

Otherwise, not only will they fail to grasp the *Dao*’s profundity,
but they must cultivate sincerity and depth of heart to ever succeed—
for those who treat oaths lightly shall lack trust,
and their regrets shall only deepen;
those who rush to inner cultivation,
favoring ease, shall often face great difficulty,
and retreat shall follow swiftly.

Such is the inevitable course of things.

Thus, the sage’s initial cultivation,
though rooted in ease and the minute,
is marked by ceaseless diligence,
unceasing caution—
for the heart’s work is never truly finished.

Only by first confronting difficulty,
then guiding it like a boat on flowing water,
doing without *doing*,
does one arrive at “no difficulty at all.”

These three lines on *“non-action”*
are the essence of pure, natural effort.
What follows—embracing difficulty in simplicity—
is the intention of seeking profound refinement through gradual approach.

As for the *Dan* method,
when speaking of *lead* and *mercury*,
what are they truly?

Let me clarify:
These substances are none other than the two poles of *yin* and *yang*.
When *mercury* is paired with *lead*,
it is as if *yin* is joined with *yang*—
after their union, primordial *qi* emerges,
then this *qi* is merged with *yin qi* in the central palace,
and thus the *elixir* is formed.

In the *Post-Heaven* realm,
*Li* is the pure *yang* of *Qian* (☰),
*Kan* is the pure *yin* of *Kun* (☷).
With the movement of *qi*,
the *Qian*’s central line enters *Kun*,
and the *Kun*’s central line enters *Qian*’s cavity—
*Qian* then becomes *Void* as *Li*,
and *Kun* becomes *full* as *Kan*.

Thus, though *Qian* is *yang* and contains *yin*,
and *Kun* is *yin* yet holds *yang*,
they are no longer the pristine *yin-yang* of the *Taiji*’s undifferentiated unity.
Yet they remain fundamentally true.

In time, the *spirit* generates *jing*,
and the *qi* transforms into *blood*—
from here, the nature of *qi* and *blood*,
and the destiny of *life-force* (*qi-shù*), emerge.

For those with thinking, perceiving minds,
and bodies of *qi*, *blood*, and form,
they are unlike the original *Qian* and *Kun*.

The adept uses method to draw forth
the *Li*’s single point of *self-mercury* (for *mercury* is the fluid of the heart,
though fluid belongs to *yin*,
it arises from *Li*’s fire and carries its nature),
and sends it down into the *Kan* palace,
to warm the *Kan* palace’s single point of *yin blood* (for *blood* is the water of *Kan*,
though water belongs to *yang*,
it is born from *Kan*’s water and is truly a cold substance)—
as the ancients said:
*“Fire enters the water domain,”*
*“Spirit enters the realm of qi.”*

Just as ice hardens when it meets fire,
or as embers heat a pot,
the *yang qi* naturally warms,
giving rise to a pulsating *yin qi* current.

Although, when fire enters water,
it is like adding embers to a pot’s base,
steaming heat ascends vigorously—
this is the birth of true *lead*.

Through the adept’s *spirit*,
the *yang qi* rises upward to the *nirvana marrow* (for governance alone),
as if baking wine in a heated pot—
the rising vapor is drawn by fire into the celestial vessel,
then condenses as dew dripping into the jar (this is what our teaching calls *“true mercury,”*
and also *“the busy messenger from the Northern Sea’s first tide,
nourishing the ancient tree’s roots in the Eastern Mountain”*—
for it is merely *qi* transformed into fluid).

Then, returning to the furnace for warmth and cultivation,
the fluid again becomes *qi*,
cycling endlessly—
ascending and descending,
until the body’s *qi* and *blood* are exhausted,
the *yin qi* stripped away,
and the mortal form is transmuted into a *golden body*,
the turbid essence into a *Qian* essence,
reverting to the original *Taiji*’s *Void*—
the *Dharma-body* of neither birth nor death.

Jia Yuanxu once said:
*“When speaking of *Kan* and *Li*,
the *lead* and *mercury* within the body,
are both ordinary *lead*—
only when *Kan* and *Li* unite,
do true *yin* and true *yang* converge,
and a single point of true *yang* emerge,
does one attain the primordial true *lead* seed.

Yet without a master’s oral instructions,
even if one forcibly restrains it,
one can only solidify the *color-body* (*sèshēn*),
and when the lower *dantian* is filled and strengthened,
it shall inevitably leak and collapse.

Scholars who attain this *yang* generation
have only completed half the work—
how could they hope to form the embryo and achieve sainthood?

Only by drawing this *yang qi* upward,
merging it with the body’s *yin jing*,
and further combining it with the *spirit marrow* (*shénsuí*)
and *essence fluid* (*língyè*) of the *nirvana marrow* and *vermilion palace*—
this is truly *“the Eastern Neighbor’s daughter (wood-mercury),
and the Western Neighbor’s son (gold-lead),
uniting as husband and wife in the chamber.”*」

chunks.translated_text:
The Yellow Crone urges one to drink *gāotú* wine,
and daily to intoxicate oneself with incense and vapor—
this is the union of *Heaven* and *Earth* to forge the elixir,
while previously, only the *Kan-Li* union produced the medicine.

With this true *lead* and true *mercury* united,
one may then refine the *returned elixir*.
*Lead* is the *gold* born from water,
*mercury* is the *wood* born from fire.
Previously, these were but common *lead* and common *mercury*,
but now they are the true *lead* and true *mercury*.

If practitioners follow this method,
cultivating the *spirit* (*shén*) without forcing the *qi*,
they shall not go astray.

**Chapter 64: Non-Doing, Non-Clinging**
The unformed is easy to grasp,
the unmanifest is easy to plan,
the fragile is easy to shatter,
the subtle is easy to disperse.
Act before it arises,
regulate before disorder begins.

A tree thick enough to embrace,
grows from a tiny sprout;
a nine-tiered tower,
begins with a single clod;
a thousand-*li* journey,
starts beneath one’s feet.

The doer brings defeat,
the clinger loses his way.
Thus, the Sage does not act,
so he never fails;
does not cling,
so he never loses.

The people’s undertakings
often falter just as completion nears.
Heed the end as the beginning,
and there shall be no failure.

Therefore, the Sage
wishes yet does not wish,
values not the treasures that are hard to obtain;
learns yet does not learn,
but corrects the errors of others.
He aids the natural unfolding of all things,
yet dares not interfere.

The *Dao* of refining one’s self
begins with restraining desire.
The key to restraining desire:
to regulate it before it arises is easy,
to regulate it as it arises is harder;
to regulate it as it arises is still easier,
but to regulate it once formed is hardest.

Therefore, the *Supreme Dao* says:
*“The unformed is easy to grasp,
the unmanifest is easy to plan.”*
When one dwells in quiet solitude,
the mind is not enslaved by affairs,
affairs do not disturb the mind—
still and unmoving, settled in its place,
one’s grasp of self and preservation of nature
is most effortless.

Moreover, in silence and obscurity,
without knowledge or perception,
no trace or sign to seek,
to then devise plans and ponder—
to dispel idle thoughts and restore sincerity—
its course is supremely smooth,
its opportunity most favorable.

Since the common *qi* is soft and fragile,
and the common mind subtle and fleeting,
before desires become entangled and relentless,
before they twist and turn without end,
to now break these impure thoughts,
to scatter these lustful hearts,
and restore the natural *Way* of Heaven,
the sincere and unerring—
how difficult would it be to sever these karmic ties,
and instantly reveal one’s original nature of *Nirvana*?

This is not another act of doing—
it is merely *“acting before it arises.”*

chunks.original_text: 古寻子防患于未萌，审机于将动，所以烟云尽扫，荆棘不生。 又如天下太平，偶有强梁小丑，乘间作乱，亦不难单骑独出，立见投诚，治之于未乱，其便固如斯也。 此炼己之工犹易就耳； 若欲修成九转，又未可以岁月计者。 胡碌碌庸流，不知道为乾坤大道，人为宇宙真人！ 或有法会偶逢，而一世竟成者； 或有因缘不遇，而数世始成者； 或有重修数动，历遇良缘，而功德未圆，性情多僻，势将成而又败，竟败而无成者。 甚矣！ 大道之奥，未易几也。 人不知道有由致，请观物所以成彼：夫合抱之木，其生也特毫末耳，因阴阳煦妪，日变月化，遂成大木焉； 九层之台，其起也，仅累土耳，因人工凑集，日新月盛，而顿见为高台焉； 又如一统山川，千里邦畿欲造其途，底其境，岂容举足便至，计程可期者哉？ 其始也，无非足下一步一步趋，由近及远，而始至其地焉。 道而曰大，实具包天容地之量，生人育物之能，岂不劳层叠而至，曲折而前乎？ 惟知道之至入，不求速效，不计近功，金玉有磨而心志不磨，春秋有变而精进不变，庶由小而大，自卑而高，从近及远，一如合抱之木，九层之台，千里之行，而顿见奇观。 虽然，道为自然之道，而功须自然之功，孟子集义生气，功在勿助勿忘。 始合天地运行，而造化维新也； 同日月往来，而光明如故也。 若使有为而为，则为者败矣； 有执而执，则执者失矣。 夫天地日月，古今运转不停者，不其无心而成化也。 倘天地有为以迭运，日月有执以推移，又安能万古不磨耶？ 谷云“天若有情天亦老，日惟无意日常明”，不其然乎？ 是以古之圣人，精修至道，妙顺天然。 为而无为，功无败也； 执而不执，德何失焉？ 奈今之从事于道者，为无为有，或作或辍，不知时行则行，时止则止，动静偶乖，与遵远矣。 又有几成而忽败，一败竟无成者矣。 《书》曰：“慎厥终，惟其始。 ”所以历亿万年而不替。 至于难得之货，人所贵也，圣人混俗和光，与人无异，独欲道而不欲货，初不知人世间有此珍重者，故不贵之，其淡泊明志如此。 它如视听言动，日用云为，其荡检踰闲者无论矣，即有从事于道，为虚为实，着有着无，皆为过失。 兹独效法前人，遵行古道，特抒意见，以为大道权衡，非不称卓卓者。 第思道为我之道，学为我之学，我自得有之而自得之，又何学之足云？ 况人多过举，我独无为。 以我无为之道，补众人之过举，即正己以正人也。 且以我无为之道，辅万物之不及，即整躬以率物也，其不敢为如此。 此圣人重德而贱货，正己以正人，民自迁善而不知为之者。 此圣人之身，即道之所寄、民物之所依，讵可一息偶为哉？ 开首言“其安易持”数句，是言玄关一窍，寂然不动，感而遂通。 且不睹不闻之际，此中有无善无恶之真。 佛曰“那个”； 儒曰“缉熙”，皆是此物。
chunks.translated_text:
The ancient sage sought to prevent calamities before their sprouts,
and discerned the opportunities at their nascent stirrings—
thus all smoke and clouds were swept away,
and thorns and brambles never took root.

Again, when the world is at great peace,
and a rogue or petty tyrant seizes the moment to cause strife,
it is no hardship for a lone horseman to emerge,
and instantly witness their surrender—
to govern before chaos arises,
how effortless the method must be!

This work of refining oneself is still easily achieved.
But to perfect the nine transformations,
time cannot be measured in mere years and months.

How many are the common, aimless folk
who fail to grasp the Dao as the grand Way of Heaven and Earth,
and humanity as the true Sage of the cosmos!
Some encounter a dharma assembly by chance
and attain fulfillment in a single lifetime;
others lack the right conditions,
and require countless lifetimes before success.
Some repeatedly cultivate, meet fortunate circumstances,
yet their virtue remains incomplete—
their nature flawed, their disposition perverse—
they nearly attain but then fail,
and fail so utterly that they never succeed.

How profound the mysteries of the Great Dao!
Few truly comprehend its ways.

Let us observe how things come to fruition:
A tree of embrace,
when first born, is but a slender sprout—
through the gentle nurture of yin and yang,
changing daily and monthly,
it grows into a mighty tree.
A nine-tiered tower,
when first raised,
is merely a pile of earth—
through human labor, gathering and refining,
ever new and ever flourishing,
it suddenly becomes a lofty tower.
Or consider the unification of mountains and rivers,
the thousand-li journey to traverse a realm—
can one expect to reach their destination
by merely lifting a foot or counting steps?
No—it begins with one step at a time,
from near to far,
until at last they arrive.

Though called the "Great Dao",
it truly encompasses the vast capacity of Heaven and Earth,
the nurturing power to birth and sustain all things—
how could it not be achieved through laborious layers,
through winding, gradual progress?

Only those who deeply enter the Dao
do not seek swift results,
do not measure gains by proximity.
Though gold and jade may be polished,
their resolve remains unshaken;
though seasons may change,
their diligence knows no variation.
Thus, from small to great,
from low to high,
from near to distant—
like the embrace of a mighty tree,
the rise of a nine-tiered tower,
a thousand-li journey—
they suddenly reveal wonders beyond compare.

Yet, the Dao is the natural Way,
and its practice demands natural effort.
Mencius spoke of *"gathering virtue and generating vital breath"*—
his power lay in *"non-action"* and *"non-forgetting."*
At first, he harmonized with the movement of Heaven and Earth,
and the renewing of creation;
later, he aligned with the ceaseless passage of sun and moon,
yet his radiance remained ever the same.
If one acts *with* intent to act,
then the actor is undone;
if one grasps *with* intent to grasp,
then the grasper is lost.

Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon,
endlessly turning through ages—
do they not achieve transformation without contrivance?

If Heaven and Earth were to act *with* intent to move,
if the sun and moon were to grasp *with* intent to shift,
how could they endure eternally without wear?

The saying goes:
*"If Heaven had emotions, Heaven too would age,
But since the sun has no will, it ever shines bright."*
Is this not the truth?

Thus, the ancient sages
refined the supreme Dao,
marvelously following nature’s course.
They acted without acting—
no failure in their deeds;
they grasped without grasping—
no loss in their virtue.

Yet today’s seekers of the Dao
mistake *non-action* for action,
sometimes practicing, sometimes abandoning—
they do not know when to move or when to rest,
when to align with the natural flow.
Their dynamic and stillness often falter,
far from the ancient path.
Some nearly succeed but then collapse,
and once fallen, never rise again.

The *Book of Documents* says:
*"Be cautious in its end,
for its beginning is all."*
Thus it endures through countless ages without replacement.

As for rare treasures,
all men hold them dear—
the sage blends with the world,
his light undimmed,
yet he seeks the Dao, not wealth.
At first, he does not know
such preciousness exists in human affairs,
so he does not value it—
his detachment is thus clear.

In matters of sight, hearing, speech, and movement,
in daily actions and common affairs—
those who abandon restraint and stray beyond bounds
need not be spoken of.
Even among those who seek the Dao,
some cling to emptiness, some to substance,
some grasp when they should not, some hold back when they should—
all are errors.

Now I alone follow the ancient path,
embrace the old Way,
and express my own views—
not to claim my words are lofty,
but to weigh the Dao’s measure.

I think the Dao is *my* Dao,
learning is *my* learning—
I attain what I attain by myself,
so why speak of learning at all?

Moreover, men often err in excess,
while I alone act without contrivance.
With my Dao of *non-action*,
I mend the errors of others—
this is to rectify myself and thereby rectify others.
And with my Dao of *non-action*,
I aid all things that fall short—
this is to order my own conduct and lead all things—
how dare I act otherwise?

The sage’s body is the Dao’s dwelling,
the people’s and all things’ reliance—
how could I for a moment cease to be?

At the outset, when I spoke of *"its effortless grasp and preservation"*,
those words referred to the single aperture of the Mysterious Pass—
silent and unmoving,
yet responsive and thus harmonious.

Even in the moments of not seeing, not hearing,
this realm holds the true essence—
neither good nor evil.
The Buddha called it *"that"*;
the Confucian sage called it *"the luminous harmony"*—
all speak of the same thing.

Since the common *qi* is soft and fragile,
and the common mind subtle and fleeting,
before desires become entangled and relentless,
before they twist and turn without end,
to now break these impure thoughts,
to scatter these lustful hearts,
and restore the natural *Way* of Heaven,
the sincere and unerring—
how difficult would it be to sever these karmic ties,
and instantly reveal one’s original nature of *Nirvana*?

This is not another act of doing—
it is merely *“acting before it arises.”*

chunks.original_text: 如初日芙蓉，晓风杨柳，娇红嫩绿，嫣然可爱。 《易》曰：“天地絪缊，万物化醇。 男女媾精，万物化生。 ”无非言初气致柔，去天未远。 朱子诗曰：“半亩方塘一鉴开，天光云影共徘徊。 ”此言道心人心，瞥眼分明。 于此持志养气，立教割断牵缠，诞登彼岸。 《礼》曰：“人生而静，天之性也。 ”感于物而动，性之欲也。 犹天地一元初复，万象回春。 虽物交物感，情欲有动，犹是天性中事，也于虚静，本乎自然。 只须些些把持，无容大费智谋，即可遏欲存诚，闲邪归正。 以萌蘖脆嫩，根芽孱弱，人欲不难立断，天理即可复还。 古人谓之玄关一窍，又曰生门死户。 以人心退藏，天心照耀，皆由未有、未乱之时，而为之、治之也。 但一阳初动，其机甚微，其势甚迅。 至于二阳三阳，则神凝气聚，真精自动，浩浩如潮生，溶溶似冰泮。 要皆自微而着，由小而大，自近而远。 至于进火进符，河车搬运，阳铅再生，阴汞复合，时烹时炼，渐结渐凝，神完气壮，药熟丹圆，更有六根震动，六通具足之盛，皆自玄关一动始也。 惟此时初动，水源至清。 古云“白虎首经至宝，华池神水真金”是也。 此时一觉而动，把持得定，由此日运己汞，包固阴精，恰如初三一痕新月，至上弦而半轮，至十五而盈满矣。 是以圣人知天下事物，无不由卑至高，由近及远，俱有自然之道在。 于是为而无为，执而无执，一若天不言四时行百物生，岂若民之隳乃事、败乃功者哉？ 若此者皆由一片虚灵，浑然无间。 自不知所欲，亦并忘为无欲。 故曰：“欲不欲。 ”至于黍珠之贵，实不曾有为，其自无而有，所以既有仍无，修道人素所自具，不待外求。 即使有所学，仍是无所学。 故曰：“学不学”。 它如以一己之纯，化天下之驳； 合天下之驳，归一己之纯，其诱掖众人，辅相万物，亦本乎自然而已矣，岂同逞其私智者哉？ 第六十五章 善为道者 古之善为道者，非以明民，将以愚之。 民之难治，以其智多。 故以智治国，国之贼； 不以智治国，国这福。 知此两者亦楷式。 常知楷式，是谓玄德。 玄德深矣。 远矣，与物反矣，然后乃至于大顺。 天下凡事尚智，惟道不尚智而尚愚，愚则近乎道矣。 圣门一贯薪传，惟愚鲁之曾子得之。 故古之圣人，以道治天下。 与民相见以道，不若与民相化于道，浑浑噩噩，同归清静之天——而一时耕田凿井者，日出而作，日入而息，忘帝力于何有，顺帝则于不知。 休哉！ 何俗之醇欤？
chunks.translated_text:
---

Like the morning sun upon lotus,
the dawn wind through willows—
tender red and fresh green,
radiant with loveliness.

*The Classic of Changes* says:
*"Heaven and Earth in their primal union,
All things refined in their transformation.
Male and female merge in essence,
All things born from this union."*

It speaks only of the initial *qi* in its gentleness,
still close to Heaven’s origin.

Zhu Xi’s verse declares:
*"A half-acre pond mirrors the sky—
Heaven’s light and clouds drift by."*

This reveals the Dao-heart and human-heart,
distinct yet clear in an instant.

Here, one steadies the will and nurtures the *qi*,
establishes teachings to sever entanglements,
and thus ascends to the other shore.

*The Rites* proclaim:
*"Man is born in stillness—
This is Heaven’s nature."*

When stirred by things, he moves—
This is the nature of desire.

Like Heaven and Earth at the first return of the cycle,
all things revive in spring.

Though things interact and stir desires,
these are still matters of Heaven’s nature,
rooted in emptiness and stillness,
natural and unforced.

Only slight restraint is needed—
no great schemes required—
to curb desire and preserve sincerity,
to quiet evil and return to right.

Like tender shoots and fragile roots,
human desire is easily severed,
while Heaven’s principle may be restored.

The ancients called this the Mysterious Pass’s aperture,
or the Gate of Life and Door of Death.

When the human heart withdraws and hides,
and the Heavenly heart shines forth,
it is because, in the time before disturbance,
one acts and governs.

Yet once the first *yang* stirs,
its mechanism is subtle,
its momentum swift.

By the second and third *yang*,
the spirit condenses, *qi* gathers,
true essence moves on its own—
vast as tides, fluid as melting ice.

All arise from the subtle to the manifest,
from small to great,
from near to far.

To the alchemical stages—
advancing fire, advancing talismans,
the River Vehicle’s transport,
rebirth of the male elixir,
reunion of the female mercury—
boiling, refining, gradually congealing,
spirit complete, *qi* robust,
the pill perfected—
even the six senses tremble,
the six powers fully manifest—
all begin with the Mysterious Pass’s first movement.

At this initial stir,
the water’s source is purest.
As the ancients said:
*"The White Tiger’s first passage—priceless treasure,
The Pool of Flowers—true gold in sacred water."*

If one awakens at this moment and acts,
holding firm, one may then daily circulate one’s own mercury,
enclosing the yin essence—
like the first crescent moon at the third day,
growing to half at the upper arc,
full at the fifteenth.

Thus the sage knows all things under Heaven,
from low to high, near to far,
follow their natural Dao.

To act without acting,
to grasp without grasping—
as Heaven speaks not yet all things move,
how unlike the people’s ruinous deeds,
their failures called success!

This is all from a single piece of pristine clarity,
undivided and whole.

Unknowing what to desire,
one forgets even the thought of desire.
Thus it is said: *"Desire not to desire."*

As for the value of millet and pearls,
there is no striving—
from non-being to being,
yet being remains non-being.
The Daoist’s inherent possession,
needing no external seeking.

Even if one studies,
it is still as if studying nothing.
Thus it is said: *"Study not to study."*

As one’s own purity transforms the world’s杂,
the world’s杂 returns to one’s own purity—
guiding and aiding all things,
rooted in nature alone.
How unlike those who flaunt their private cleverness!

---

**Chapter 65: The Skillful Daoist**

The ancients skilled in the Dao
did not enlighten the people—
they sought to make them simple.

The people’s difficulty in governance
lies in their excess of cleverness.

Thus, ruling with cleverness
is a state’s ruin;
ruling without cleverness
brings the state’s blessing.

Knowing these two principles
is called the Mysterious Virtue.

The Mysterious Virtue is profound,
far-reaching, contrary to things—
only then does one attain Great Harmony.

Under Heaven, all affairs rely on cleverness,
yet the Dao does not rely on cleverness—
it relies on simplicity.
Simplicity is near to the Dao.

The Master’s lineage, passed down,
was grasped by the simpleminded Zengzi.

Thus the ancient sages
governed under Heaven with the Dao.
They did not merely show the people the Dao—
they transformed them into the Dao,
mysterious and indistinct,
all returning to the pure stillness of Heaven—
while the plowman and well-digger
rise with the sun and rest with the moon,
forgetting imperial might in their labor,
following Heaven without knowing it.

Ah! How pure their simplicity!

chunks.original_text: 降及后世，士大夫不尚愚而尚智，则机械频生，人心愈坏，贪鄙日甚，风俗弥偷。 斯民之败度灭礼，犯法违条，愍不畏死者，殊难枚举。 要皆尚才华重聪明之智者，希图取伪，斯民之愚者亦好阴谋。 民之天真凿矣。 诡谲多矣，而熙来攘往，彼诈此虞，为上者固有治之不胜治者焉。 故曰：“以智治国国之贼，不以智治国国之福。 ”其故何哉？ 盖使民有知识，已破其浑沌之真； 若能不识不知，乃完其无名之朴。 两者智愚分焉，利害判焉。 与其尚智而害，何如尚愚而获利？ 知此两者，非但治世如是，即修身亦然，均堪为楷式焉。 知此楷式，则近道矣。 大修行人，于不睹不闻也，返其无思无虑之神，非屏耳目，黜聪明，不能归于定静也。 苟有一毫计较，一念谋为，则太朴不完，混沌不天丧矣。 知智之有损于己，愚之有益于身，不逞其智，乐守其愚，是即谓之玄德。 大凡可名者非玄德，惟不可以名言，深无其极，远莫能知，乃可为玄德。 虽与飞潜动植，蚩蚩蠢蠢之物，同一无欲无知，但物不能即绪穷源，终日昏膭而已； 人则由粗及精，从原达委，以至于三元合一，太极归真，犹可底于神化，不诚与物反哉？ 治国不尚智，而修道尤贵愚。 诚以智为国之贼，愚为道之种也。 夫愚可以为道种哉？ 试思混沌中无念虑、无知识，非所谓愚耶？ 忽焉一觉，即是我不生不灭本来。 人莫说把持此觉，修成无上正等正觉，方能免却轮回，不受阴阳鼓铸，不为鬼神拘执； 即此混混沌沌中，忽然一觉，我以真意守而不散，此一觉已到般若波罗蜜。 果能拳拳服膺，常常把持，而轮回种子，即从此断矣。 若另起一念、生一见，就是后天识欲之神夹杂其中，所谓“无量动来生死本，痴人唤作本来人”是也。 要之，神一也，有欲则为二矣。 二意三心，即是杂妄根尘，所以有生死之路。 惟有一心，无二念，有正念，无妄心，道在是矣。 若能并将此一心正念而悉化之，是为太极还于无极，金仙之成即在此炼虚之中。 何谓炼虚？ 即如混沌之际，懵懵懂懂，如愚如醉，无觉无知即虚也。 坐功到无人无我，何地何天，即炼虚也。 又曰学道之要，始而忘人，继而忘我，终而忘法，以至于忘忘之极，乃为究竟。 人能以把此一刻为主，以真觉为用，道不远矣。 然炼虚之法虽是如此，其功必自炼性始。 炼性古人名为铸镜也。 若心有不炼，则昏昏罔罔，冥然无觉，虽近在眼前，尚且不知，何况具六通者乎？ 若皆由私欲之杂乱其心志，而未至于虚也。 如真觉之后，不许一丝半蒂存于胸中，即灵台之宝镜常放光明，而又非必功满行圆，乃放毫光也。 即此混混沌沌中忽然一知，不复它知，忽然一觉，不更它觉，此一刻中即洞彻光明，四达不侼。 虽然，学人满腔私欲，忽期洁白晶莹，如玉如金，夫岂一念之虚能了哉？ 必要先铸雌雄二剑，以去有形地无形之魔。 此剑不利，则欲魔、色魔、天魔、人魔，难以扫除净尽、现出乾元真面目也。 盖人欲天理，混杂多年，虽欲独立中流，势有难于抵敌者。 以故明知之而明蹈之，皆由引之入人欲者众，引之入天理者少也。 今为学人告，欲成清净法身，必先有清净之神； 欲得清净之神，必有浩荡之气。 所云铸剑无它，即由平旦之气，直养无害，以至于浩然刚大。
chunks.translated_text:
「From the later generations onward,
scholars and officials no longer valued *qu* (愚) but prized cleverness,
thus giving rise to ever-more intricate schemes,
corrupting the hearts of men,
deepening their avarice and vulgarity daily,
and rendering customs ever more deceitful.

The ruin of these people’s moral standards and rites,
their lawbreaking and transgression of regulations,
their disregard for death—
such cases are countless and difficult to enumerate.

All stem from those who extol talent and favor acute intelligence,
striving to gain falsehood,
while even the simple among the people indulge in guile.
The people’s innate purity has been pierced through,
deceit and cunning abound,
yet in their ceaseless bustle,
one deceives while another fears,
and those in authority find governance beyond their capacity.

Thus it is said:
*"To rule a nation with cleverness is to make it a thief;
to rule without cleverness is to bring it fortune."*

Why is this so?
Because when the people acquire knowledge,
their primordial simplicity is already shattered.
If they remain in ignorance, unaware,
then their original purity endures intact.

These two paths—cleverness and simplicity—diverge,
and their benefits and harms are starkly contrasted.
Rather than value cleverness and invite harm,
why not embrace simplicity and reap its gains?

Understanding these two principles
is not only true for governing the world—
it applies equally to cultivating oneself,
serving as a model to follow.

To grasp this model
is to approach the Dao.

Great cultivators,
even when they see and hear nothing,
return to the state of no thought, no care—
the divine essence of pure stillness.
This cannot be achieved
by merely closing ears and eyes,
or by suppressing acute intelligence,
but only through attaining true equanimity.

If even a single thread of calculation or scheming arises,
the original purity is lost,
and the harmony of simplicity is ruined.

Knowing that cleverness harms oneself,
while simplicity benefits the body,
one should not flaunt their cleverness,
but delight in preserving their simplicity—
this is what is called the *Mysterious Virtue* (玄德).

All that can be named is not the *Mysterious Virtue*;
only that which cannot be named,
profound and boundless,
far-reaching and unfathomable,
can be called the *Mysterious Virtue*.

Though it shares with flying and creeping things,
and with the sluggish and dull,
the quality of having no desires, no knowledge,
yet these creatures cannot grasp the threads of their origins,
living in perpetual darkness and confusion.

Man alone,
from coarse to refined,
from origin to conclusion,
may reach the unity of the Three Primordials (三元),
returning the Great Ultimate (太极) to its original state (归真),
and still attain divine transformation—
how could this not be contrary to things?

In governing a nation, cleverness is not valued,
but in cultivating the Dao, simplicity is all the more precious.
For cleverness is indeed the thief of a nation,
while simplicity is the seed of the Dao.

Can simplicity truly be the seed of the Dao?
Consider the state of *Hun Dun* (混沌),
where there is no thought, no care,
no knowledge—
is this not what is called simplicity?

Suddenly, one awakens—
this is the unborn, unending essence of *I* (我).
None should claim to retain this awakening,
to cultivate the supreme and perfect enlightenment (無上正等正覺),
for only then can one escape the cycle of rebirth,
avoid the forging of yin and yang (陰陽鼓鑄),
and not be ensnared by ghosts and spirits (鬼神拘執).

Even within the *Hun Dun* state,
when one suddenly awakens—
if I guard this true essence without letting it disperse,
this single awakening has already reached *Prajñāpāramitā* (般若波羅蜜).

If one steadfastly upholds and constantly guards it,
the seeds of rebirth will be severed here.

If another thought or perception arises,
it is the post-natal *desire-knowledge* (後天識欲之神) mingling within,
as the saying goes:
*"Countless movements bring forth the root of birth and death,
The foolish call it the original man."* (無量動來生死本，痴人唤作本来人)

In essence,
the divine essence is singular,
but desire makes it dual.

Dual thoughts and triple minds
are the defiled roots and dust—
the cause of birth and death.

Only with one heart,
no dual thoughts,
having right awareness (正念),
and no deluded mind (妄心),
is the Dao found.

If one can dissolve even this single heart and right awareness,
it is the Great Ultimate returning to the Non-Ultimate (太極還於無極),
and the formation of the *Jin Xian* (金仙) lies within this refining of the void (炼虚).

What is *refining of the void* (炼虚)?
It is like the state of *Hun Dun*,
confused and befuddled,
as if in simplicity or drunkenness,
having no knowledge, no awareness—
this is the void.

When seated meditation reaches the stage of no person, no self,
no place, no sky,
this too is refining of the void.

It is also said:
The essentials of learning the Dao
begin with forgetting the self,
proceed to forgetting others,
and end with forgetting the Dao itself—
until one reaches the extreme of forgetting-forgetting,
this is the ultimate attainment.

If one can take this single moment as their master,
and use true awakening as their means,
the Dao is not far.

Yet though the method of refining the void is thus,
its practice must begin with refining the nature (炼性).
The ancients named refining the nature *casting the mirror* (鑄鏡).

If the mind is not refined,
one remains dim and unaware,
even if the truth is right before their eyes—
how much more so for those who possess the Six Perfections (六通)?

If the heart is still clouded by private desires,
it has not yet reached the void.

As in the state after true awakening,
one must not allow even a thread or speck of desire to remain in the chest—
then the *Ling Tai* (靈台) mirror’s treasure
will always shine brightly,
though not necessarily in full attainment,
but in a radiant gleam.

Even within the *Hun Dun* state,
when one suddenly knows—
knowing nothing else—
suddenly awakens—
awakening to nothing more—
this single moment reveals boundless clarity,
illuminating all four directions without obstruction.

However,
a student filled with private desires
cannot suddenly become pure and transparent,
like jade or gold.
How could this be achieved
by a mere moment of emptiness?

One must first forge the *female* and *male blades* (雌雄二劍),
to eliminate both the visible and invisible demons (魔).

If these blades are not sharp,
the demons of desire (欲魔),
form (色魔),
heaven (天魔),
and man (人魔)
cannot be swept away and thoroughly purified,
revealing the true face of the Primordial (乾元).

For human desires and heavenly principles (天理)
have long been entangled;
though one seeks to stand alone in the stream,
the forces opposing them are too great.

Thus, though they know the truth,
they still tread upon it—
for those who lead them into human desires are many,
while those who guide them toward heavenly principles are few.

Now I tell the students:
To perfect the pure *Dharma-body* (法身),
one must first have a pure *divine essence* (神);
To obtain a pure *divine essence*,
one must cultivate boundless *qi* (氣).

What is called *casting the blades* (鑄劍) has no other means—
it is by nurturing the *qi* of the early morning (平旦之氣),
direct and unharmful,
until it becomes vast and robust,
great and firm.»

The Master’s lineage, passed down,
was grasped by the simpleminded Zengzi.

Thus the ancient sages
governed under Heaven with the Dao.
They did not merely show the people the Dao—
they transformed them into the Dao,
mysterious and indistinct,
all returning to the pure stillness of Heaven—
while the plowman and well-digger

chunks.original_text: 斯神剑成而锋芒利，可以斩妖断邪。 斯时也，莫说淫声、绝色入目而心不乱，即有美女同眠，亦不知也； 莫说凶魔恶曜到身边而神自如，即有泰山崩前亦不畏也。 此神剑之造成者，自有志气如神之一候，只恐工行不深，或作或辍，不肯当下立定脚跟耳。 若能一刀两断，一私起即灭除，灭除不复再生，此断生死轮回之路矣。 学道人别无它妙，只怕认不得明镜神剑耳。 如能认得，此刻中有明镜普照，恶妄不容，慧剑长悬，欲魔立断，自此一念把持将去，然后神室可成，而仙丹可炼矣。 此明镜慧剑，为修道人之要务。 设剑锋不利，安能断绝邪魔？ 所以心愈制而愈乱也。 宝镜无光，难以分别理欲，所以己弥克而弥多也。 孟子言养气而不言养心，诚谓气足而心自定耳。 彼徒强制夫心，而不知集义生气，去道远矣。 李二曲云：“人心本自乐，自将私欲缚。 私欲一萌时，良知还自觉。 一觉便消除，此心依旧乐。 ”拙翁云：“光明寂照遍河沙，凡圣原来共一家。 一念不生全体现，六根才动被云遮。 断除烦恼重增病，趋向真如亦是邪。 世事随缘无挂碍，涅盘生死等空华。 ”有心性学者，当三复斯言！ 第六十六章 为百谷王 江海所以能为百谷王者，以其善下之，故能为百谷王。 是以圣人欲上人，必以言下之； 欲先人，必以身后之。 是以圣人处上而人不重，入前而人不害。 是以天下乐推而不厌。 以其不争，故天下莫能与之争。 夫人莫不愿人之服己也，乃有不欲服而人服，益欲服而人愈不服者，无它，以其自高自大，而不肯低其心下其气也。 试观江海为百谷之所归往者，以其能下之故，所以为百谷王。 设江海如百谷之自处于上，百谷虽有归往之势，奈彼无容受何？ 是以圣人早见及此，欲上人必以言下之，如尧之咨于四岳，舜之询于四门——举凡教条号令，事事访于臣邻而不自高其智，此所以愈下而人愈上也。 欲先人必以身后之，如禹皋伊旦，虽属先知先觉，而在在让人以先，自处以后，此所以愈后而人愈先也。 惟其自处于下与后，虽居帝王之位，而无震慑之威，所以不重也。 掌神灵之统，而无凌厉之气，所以不害也。 故天下乐推而为先，绝无厌恶之心焉。 《诗》曰：“在彼无恶，在此无斁。 庶几夙夜，以永终誉。 ”此岂有它哉？ 以其不争人上不争人先，而人自上之先之，服教畏神，沐恩戴德之不已，又安忍争上争先，而与圣人角胜竞长也哉？ 此喻炼丹之学，始以神火下入丹田，然后火蒸水沸，水底金生，长生之药始得而有。 夫人受天地之中以生，原是完完全全； 自有生后，气质拘之，物欲蔽之，所得于天之元气，悉散漫于一身尸气之间，不能荟萃一区者久矣。 今欲攒簇五行，和合四象，会于中宫，归于玄窍，其必万缘放下，一私不起，垂帘塞兑，以目视鼻，由鼻对脐，降心火于丹田——不过片响工夫，即见玄关窍开，一阳来复，周身之气，自然齐集丹田，融融泄泄，乐不可名。 但观照之初，火不紧则金不出矿，火太猛则又烧灼精血，窒窒灵机。 惟有不粘不脱，若有若无，而下丹田之气自跃跃欲动。 此犹江海之能下百谷，百谷所以归往。 圣人能下天下，天下所以归心。 夫人一身，心为至大至贵，百体皆小焉贱焉者耳。
chunks.translated_text:
Once the divine sword is forged and its edge sharp,
it can cleave demons and sever evil.
At that time—
no longer will lewd sounds or ravishing beauty
disturb the mind upon sight,
nor will even shared slumber with a fair woman
rouse awareness;
no longer will malevolent spirits or ominous omens
shake the spirit,
nor will the collapse of Tai Mountain before one’s eyes
inspire fear.

This forging of the divine sword
depends on a will as resolute as the gods—
yet alas, the practice is not deep-rooted,
sometimes pursued, sometimes abandoned,
unwilling to stand firm in the present moment.

If one can sever with a single stroke,
and extinguish private desires the instant they arise,
never allowing them to regenerate—
this is the path to breaking the wheel of birth and death.

The Daoist student has no other secret—
only fear of failing to recognize
the mirror-like divine sword.

If recognized,
the mirror’s light shines universally in this instant,
admitting no evil or delusion,
the wisdom-sword hangs suspended—
desire-demons are instantly severed.
From this moment, with a single thought held firm,
the divine chamber may be perfected,
and the immortal elixir refined.

This mirror-like wisdom-sword
is the essential task of the cultivator.

If the sword’s edge is dull,
how can it sever demonic forces?
Thus, the more one restrains the heart,
the more it grows disordered.

If the precious mirror lacks luminosity,
how can one distinguish principle from desire?
Thus, the more one strives to suppress,
the more they multiply.

Mencius spoke of nurturing *qi* but not of nurturing the heart—
truly, when *qi* is abundant, the heart naturally settles.
Those who merely force the heart,
without knowing that righteousness generates *qi*,
are far from the Dao.

Li Erqu said:
*"The human heart is naturally joyous,
yet private desires bind it.
When desire first stirs,
the true mind becomes aware.
Once aware, it vanishes—
the heart returns to its original joy."*

The humble old man said:
*"Luminous and silent, pervading the sands of the river,
the vulgar and the sage share the same home.
When not a thought arises, the whole body manifests;
the six senses stir—clouds obscure the view.
Severing vexation only deepens affliction,
seeking true suchness is itself delusion.
Worldly affairs follow their course without obstruction,
nirvana and birth-death are but empty flowers."*

Let those who study mind and nature
meditate deeply on these words.

**Chapter 66: On the King of All Valleys**

The reason the rivers and seas can be the sovereign of all valleys
is that they excel in humility,
and thus become the sovereign of all valleys.

Therefore, the Sage who wishes to surpass others
must first speak in a way that places himself below them;
who wishes to lead others
must first position himself behind them.

Thus, the Sage, though in the highest place,
does not inspire awe,
and though he moves forward,
he does not harm others.
Hence, all under heaven willingly follow without exhaustion.

Because he does not contend,
none can contend with him.

All desire others to submit to them,
yet some, though not submitting, are submitted to,
while others, though eager to submit, are ever more resisted—
this is because they exalt themselves,
unwilling to lower their hearts or humble their *qi*.

Observe how rivers and seas become the gathering place of all valleys—
it is because they receive them from below,
and thus become their sovereign.
If rivers and seas were to place themselves above the valleys,
though the valleys might still flow toward them,
where would be their capacity to contain them?

Thus, the Sage perceives this early:
to surpass others, he must speak from a lower place,
as Yao consulted the Four Mountains,
and Shun inquired of the Four Gates—
all teachings, commands, and matters
were sought from ministers and neighbors,
never exalting his own wisdom.
This is why the more he humbles himself,
the more others elevate him.

To lead others, he must place himself behind them,
as Yu, Gao, and Yi did—
though they were enlightened first,
they always yielded precedence to others,
placing themselves last.
This is why the more he retreats,
the more others advance.

Because he positions himself below and behind,
even as emperor, he lacks the terror of authority,
and thus is not feared.
Though he governs the divine and human,
he lacks the harshness of domination,
and thus does not harm others.
Therefore, all under heaven willingly follow him as their leader,
with no resentment.

The *Odes* say:
*"There is no blame in him,
nor in me any fault.
May we thus, night and day,
perpetuate our good name."*

What else is this but this?
Because he does not contend for superiority or precedence,
others naturally place him above and before him.
They submit to his teachings, revere his spirit,
and endlessly receive his grace and virtue—
how could they then dare to contend for superiority or precedence,
and rival the Sage in competition?

This is the analogy for elixir cultivation:
first, the divine fire descends into the elixir field,
then the fire steams and the water boils,
and from the depths of the water, gold is born—
only then does the elixir of longevity begin to manifest.

Humans receive the central *qi* of Heaven and Earth to live,
originally complete and whole.
Yet after birth, *qi* and constitution constrain them,
and desires obscure them,
so that the original *qi* of Heaven
is scattered and dissipated throughout the body’s stale *qi*,
unable to gather in one place for long.

Now, to converge the Five Phases,
harmonize the Four Symbols,
unite them in the central palace,
and return them to the mysterious orifice—
one must first release all entanglements,
allow no private thoughts to arise,
close the eyes and seal the mouth,
so that the eyes see through the nose,
the nose faces the navel,
and the heart-fire descends into the elixir field—
in but a moment, the mysterious pass opens,
one *yang* revives,
and the *qi* of the whole body
naturally gathers in the elixir field,
fusing and flowing freely,
a joy beyond words.

Yet at the outset of observation,
if the fire is not intense, the gold will not emerge from the ore;
if the fire is too fierce, it will scorch the essence and blood,
stifling the vital spark.
Only when it is neither clinging nor detached,
neither present nor absent,
does the *qi* of the elixir field leap with restless energy.

This is like the rivers and seas receiving all valleys—
thus the valleys gather toward them.
The Sage receives all under heaven—
thus all hearts turn to him.

In a single body,
the heart is the most noble and exalted,
while all other limbs are small and lowly.

The **Taoist Sage** thus likens the heart to the vastness of the rivers and seas,
and all other limbs to the smallness of the valleys and the lowliness of the common folk—
this is the **elixir field** of the body.

Those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** must likewise take the lowly as their foundation,
the humble as their root,
yet not place themselves above the noble and exalted,
so that they may descend to the common and ordinary—
then their attainment will be effortless.

For the ordinary man,
the spirit (*shen*) is the master,
while *qi* follows its movements, rising and falling,
thus giving birth to sons and daughters,
and life and death.

The **Perfect Sage** (*Zhiren*) takes *qi* as the master,
while the spirit listens and moves at its command.
As the *Wuzhen* says: *"Though others act as master, I am the guest."*

The great adept,
when *qi* moves,
inverts the workings of **Nature** (*Zao*) and **Transformation** (*Hua*),
upsets the **Heaven-Earth** (*Qiankun*) polarity,
and simply follows its ascending and descending flow—
returning to the furnace to seal and refine,
then awaiting the **True Essence** (*Zhenxin*) to manifest,
cycling and revolving in harmony,
never relying on the spirit for guidance.

Yet when one observes the **True Qi** (*Zhenqi*) surging and blending,
inverting and reversing its course,
and completes the ninefold transformation,
the **elixir** (*dantian*) matures and the **Pearl** (*zhuzhu*) awakens—
is this not a lofty state,
exalted above all,
the object of reverence for ten thousand men,
the spectacle of all under heaven?

Only when one abides in the lowly and follows behind in this manner,
does the spirit of **lively detachment** (*huodantian*) arise—
a heart of humility and modesty,
thus avoiding the calamities of **tilting the elixir field** (*qīdān dǎodìng*),
**mercury fleeing** (*gǒngzǒu*),
and **lead scattering** (*qiānfēi*).

Hence, when one remains in the lowly without striving,
all under heaven cannot contend with him.

**Chapter Sixty-Seventh**
I possess the **Three Treasures** (*Sān Bǎo*),
and all under heaven call me great—
yet this seems unworthy.

For only the truly great can appear unworthy;
if one seems worthy,
it is long since one has been small.

I possess the **Three Treasures**,
and cling to them in safeguarding:
the first is **compassion** (*cí*),
the second is **frugality** (*jiǎn*),
the third is **not daring to lead all under heaven** (*bù gǎn wéi tiānxià xiān*).

For **compassion** brings forth **courage** (*yǒng*);
**frugality** brings forth **breadth** (*guǎng*);
and **not daring to lead all under heaven**,
thus one can fulfill one’s role and endure.

Now, if one abandons **compassion** for **courage**,
**frugality** for **breadth**,
and **not daring to lead** for **leading ahead**,
then one is already dead.

For **compassion**—
when wielded in battle, it wins;
when used in defense, it holds firm.
When **Heaven** intends to save a man,
it shields him with **compassion**.

The **Dao/Way** is fundamentally **Limitless** (*Wújí*), yet it is also the **Great Ultimate** (*Tàijí*).
Neither great nor small,
neither great nor small—
it is both great and small at once.

There are indeed words that no thought or speculation can exhaust.
If one insists on calling it "great,"
then it is *"the boundless and mighty **Harmonious Qi** (*Hàorán qì*),*
*filling the space between Heaven and Earth."*

If one seeks to describe it as "small,"
then it is *"the nameless **embryo** (*pǔ*),*
*most subtle and minute,*
*hidden in the boundless expanse."*

In man,
its possession means life,
its loss means death.

All arise from the **Limitless** yet take form,
from the **invisible** yet manifest.
Truly, the small is its origin,
while the great is its unfolding.

It is better to speak of the small to reveal the **Dao/Way**,
than to speak of the great to explain it.

Thus the **Taoist Sage** says:
*"All under heaven call me great."*

For **"I"** is the **Dao/Way** itself.
The **Dao/Way** has no fixed form or body;
yet when called "great,"
it seems to have a form and body that can be likened—
this does not truly resemble the **Dao/Way**.

If one wishes to embody **Heaven’s Dao/Way**,
and resemble the Sage’s form,
from the opening of **Heaven** to the present day,
those who have established **Heaven’s polarity** (*Lìjí*) and expounded the **Dao/Way** and its teachings—
for ages now,
they have all relied on the **Limitless** as the **Ultimate**,
the **unmanifest** as the **manifest**,
the most subtle and minute as the **Dao/Way**.

Yet how can one practice the **Dao/Way** when it is **soundless and odorless** (*wúshēng wúchòu*),
flickering and indistinct?
How can the student begin?

The **Taoist Sage** says:
*"I possess the **Three Treasures**,
and cling to them in safeguarding."*

If one holds them steadfastly without loss,
treasures them as precious,
never forgetting them in each thought,
then one may return to the origin
and restore the **Primordial Sovereign** (*Wéihuáng*)’s descent.

What are the **Three Treasures**?
The first is **compassion** (*cí*), which is **benevolence** (*rén*) itself.
**Benevolence** and **compassion**, gentle and pervasive,
are the **elemental principle** (*yuán*) of **Heaven**.
The gentleman embodies **benevolence**,
and this suffices to nurture all men.

Moreover, it encompasses the **Four Beginnings** (*Sì Duān*),
and includes all **virtues** (*shàn*).
**Benevolence** is within it—
then the **Dao/Way** is within it.
Filling and exhausting it,
it can embrace **Heaven and Earth**,
and permeate **ancient and modern**.

This is the **foundation of the Golden Elixir** (*Jīndān zhī běn*),
and the adept must cherish and remember it.

Yet its **Dao/Way** extends to the utmost greatness,
while its **root** (*míng*) ascends from the utmost subtlety.
If one does not know to **forget all thoughts** (*wànniàn jū wàng*),
and **illuminate the inner essence** (*yīlíng nèizhào*),
but instead merely pursues breadth and becomes dissipated,
seeks vastness and wanders aimlessly,
then one will gain nothing of **benevolence**,
and nothing of the **Dao/Way**.

Only when one **inverts and seeks within oneself** (*fǎnqiú*),
and **steadfastly guards the heart** (*dǔshǒu zhū xīn*),
does one establish oneself while also establishing others,
and reach fulfillment while also fulfilling others.
Guarding the narrow yet applying the broad—
this is what the ancients called **"obtaining one, all things are accomplished"** (*dé yī wànshì bì*),
is it not the essence of **frugality** (*jiǎn*)?

For **frugality** is the means to seek **benevolence**,
and the key to cultivating the **Dao/Way**.
The student, having known **compassion**,
must further nourish it with **frugality**,
then alone may he align with the **Dao/Way**.

Yet if one exalts himself in pride,
and magnifies his own greatness,
without the measure of humility and modesty,
then within he knows only himself,
and without he scorns all others.
He boasts of his cleverness,
and arrogantly proclaims his wisdom,
truly believing he is the first to awaken and harmonize—
often he regards all under heaven as incapable of surpassing him.

In the end,
his nature is not **serene and tranquil** (*tiánjìng*),
his *qi* is not **harmonious and peaceful** (*héping*),
and yet he hopes to complete the **Nine Turns of the Elixir** (*jiǔ zhuǎn dānchéng*),
and reach the **Nine Heavens of the Dao/Way** (*jiǔ tiān dǎojí*)—
this is indeed difficult.

The ancients said:
*"The essential key to refining the elixir*
*is to take **awakened awareness** (*língjué*) as the **Dao/Way’s body**,*
*and **harmonious blending** (*chōnghé*) as the **Dao/Way’s function**—*
*then, in all things and places,*
*one must not dare to lead all under heaven."*

Moreover, **compassion** (*cí*) is the **innate capacity** (*liángnéng*) of man’s heart.
Exhausting one’s own heart to establish the **fate** (*mìng*) of all things,
what a vast **vow** (*shìyuàn*) this is!
Nurturing the **sincere and upright** (*cùnzhōng*) nature within,
to seek the **peace** (*ān*) of all things,
what a mighty **precision** (*jīnglì*) and **strength** (*liàng*) this is!

Thus the man who guards **compassion** is the same as the man who nourishes **courage**.
**Zengzi** told **Zixiang**:
*"When reflecting upon oneself without shrinking,*
*even if one is clad in coarse garments and broadcloth,*
*I would not fear."*

「If one reflects upon oneself and shrinks back,
even if there are a thousand people,
I would still go forward.

*Is it not the man who casts aside all private thoughts of self-interest,*
*who can possess such great courage?*

**Courage** (*yǒng*) must be rooted in restraint (*yuē*) before it can be expressed broadly (*bó*).
If one does not restrain, how can one be broad?

Only when one can **prudently** (*shèn*) govern one’s actions,
**sparingly** (*shěng*) consider one’s thoughts,
**dedicate** (*zhì*) a single mind to the **rectifying field** (*fāngcùn*),
**gather** (*shōu*) all the **hundreds of limbs** (*bǎitiǎn*) to the **elixir field** (*dāntián*),
**unceasingly** (*miánmiánmìmì*) and **unflaggingly** (*bù'èrbùxī*), **continuously** (*jìjì*) and **purely** (*chúnchún*),
**without slackness** (*wúdài*) or **neglect** (*wúhuāng*),
then **naturally** (*zìrán*) one’s **self-cultivation** (*xiūshēn*) will be complete,
and **all under heaven** (*tiānxià*) will find **peace** (*píng*).

*How else could one achieve such breadth if not through frugality?*

As for **not daring to lead all under heaven** (*bùgǎnwéitiānxiàxiān*),
it is the **proper humility** (*qiānzūn*) and **radiant virtue** (*guāng*) of **steadfastness** (*ānzhēn*).
**Gentleness** (*róushùn*) and **yielding** (*róushùn*) to all under heaven,
while none under heaven dare to contend with him—
this is to **align with** (*shùnchéng*) the **Dao/Way’s unfolding** (*tiāndào*),
and the **Dao/Way** will **silently** (*mò*) grant its completion (*chéng*).

*Without the **virtue/power** (*dé*) of **harmonious blending** (*chōnghé*),*
*how could one dare not to lead all under heaven,*
*and still achieve a **great instrument’s** (*dàqì*) late fulfillment (*wǎnchéng*) like this?*

Thus, **compassion** (*cí*), **frugality** (*jiǎn*), and **yielding** (*hòu*)
are all the **foundations** (*běnshǐ*) of seeking the **Dao/Way**.
**Courage** (*yǒng*), **breadth** (*guǎng*), and **leading** (*xiān*)
are all the **ultimate expressions** (*mòxiào*) of following the **Dao/Way**.

Yet today’s scholars are otherwise:
**Discarding compassion** (*shěcí*) yet **pursuing courage** (*qǐyǒng*), they will **nurture a cruel heart** (*shēngrényīnxīn*);
**Discarding frugality** (*shějiǎn*) yet **seeking breadth** (*qǐguǎng*), they will **harbor greedy desires** (*xīn huái tānniàn*);
**Discarding yielding** (*shěhòu*) yet **striving to lead** (*qǐxiān*), they will **engage in rivalry** (*bǔyǒuchéng*—*contesting competition*).

*All are paths that lead to death.*
Even if they **chance to survive** (*xìngcún*),
they are but **living corpses** (*xíngshī*), **wandering flesh** (*zǒuròu*),
**mingling indiscriminately** (*làncè*) among the masses (*rénqún*),
*what difference is there between them and the dead?*

In summary, **compassion** is the **natural principle** (*shēnglǐ*) of man,
a **shared essence** (*xìng suǒ tóngrán*) within all.
Only when one **guards it with restraint** (*shǒuzhīyǐyuē*) and **expresses it in harmony** (*chūzhīyǐhé*),
will **compassionate benevolence** (*cíhuì*) and **tender concern** (*cèdá*) flow forth from **true sincerity** (*zìchū zhēnchéng*),
and **none under heaven** (*tiānxià*) will fail to **bow in submission** (*xīnzhé*) and **yield** (*qūshì*).

*When benevolence suffices to benefit others,*
*a **compassionate man** (*rénzhě*) is **unmatched** (*wúdí*),
*how could there ever be defeat in battle,*
*or failure in defense,*
*bringing shame upon all under heaven?*

The *Book of Documents* (*Shū*) says:
*"Only the **Heavenly** (*wéitiān*) **obscures** (*yīn*) and **nourishes** (*bì*) the people below,
**harmonizing** (*xiángxié*) their dwelling in **cooperation** (*xiángxié*)."*
*Granting them life and fulfillment* (*yǐshēngyǐsuì*),
they **endure** (*yǒngxiǎng*) the **eternal peace** (*wúshì*) of **Heaven** (*tiān*),
*this is what is called the **Heaven’s intent to save** (*tiān jiāng jiùzhī*) them.*

The *Book of Odes* (*Shījīng*) says:
*"The **Heaven’s command** (*wéitiānzhīmìng*) is **profoundly harmonious** (*yúmù*) and **unceasing** (*bùyǐ*)."*
*It reveals the **clear and boundless qi** (*qīngkōngyīqì*),*
**flowing and unending** (*liúxíngbùxī*), **nurturing and limitless** (*fāyùwújiāng*),
*and it is said that **compassion alone** (*cíwèizhī*) suffices to **guard** (*wèi*) it.*

The **Dao/Way** is called the **Great Dao/Way** (*Dàdào*),
*its essence is **boundless** (*wújí*) yet the **Supreme Ultimate** (*Tàijí*).*
Yet if one does not **trace its origin from the boundless** (*cóngwújízhīshǐ*),
**searching** (*zhǐ*) for a **foothold** (*jīnyá*) in the **chaotic indistinctness** (*húnhúndùn*),
how could one **fathom** (*cè*) the **root of the Supreme Ultimate** (*Tàijízhīgēn*)?
How could one **measure** (*mì*) its **beginning and end** (*qǐzhǐ*)?

Scholars must first **clarify the Dao’s source** (*Dàoyuán*).
In the **unseen and unheard** (*bùshòubùwén*),
they must **seek out** (*zhǐ*) the **most subtle and profound essence** (*zhìyǐnzhìwēizhītǐ*),
*this is what is called the **void yet responsive** (*xūérlíng*).*

Yet its **subtlety is already extreme** (*guǎnqíxiàyǐshèn*),
*like a single grain of millet* (*shǔzhūyīlì*)—
*and there is something that can be **imagined** (*xiàng*).*

In totality, it is **form without form** (*wúxíngzhīxíng*),
**state without state** (*wúzhuàngzhīzhuàng*).
**Approach it and one does not see its head** (*yíngzhībùjiànqíshǒu*),
**follow it and one does not see its tail** (*suízhībùjiànqíhòu*).
*This is the **warm and luminous compassion** (*ǎirán yīpiàn cíhuì*) within man’s heart.*

Even the **most stubborn and base** (*suǒwéizhuānzuì*) of men,
*does not **extinguish** (*mǐn*) the **compassion** (*cízhīxìng*) within them.*
Confucius said:
*"If I seek **virtue/power** (*rén*), then **virtue/power** (*rén*) will **immediately** (*sī*) come to me."*

*I would not fear."*

chunks.original_text: ”修丹岂有它哉？ 不过守此仁慈而已。 何谓仁慈？ 如齐王见牛之觳觫而不忍，乡人见懦子坠井而恻然，此皆仁心发端，天心来复。 由此思之，此个动机动念，无时不有，第恐人不及觉耳。 学者从天真发动处，扩充行去，自为炼丹有基。 但不可务博而荒，只须守约而微。 一心扳命，五体投诚。 古云：“心要在腔子里，念不出总持门。 ”由此愈约愈博，愈微愈彰。 其约弥精者，其拓之愈广也。 学者可不以俭为本乎？ 虽然俭德为怀，固以约鲜失之良法，苟不出以谦和，又恐躁暴之性，起火伤丹，故守约尤须至和，在在自卑自小，不居人先，始为虚己下人。 仁心常存，道气常存矣。 若不尚慈而尚勇，不务俭而务广，不居后而居先，如此则心是凡有也，安望我有三宝持而不失乎？ 且人有仁慈，尤足得人之欢心，以之出战，战必胜； 以之守城，城必固。 此即喻临炉进火，烧退木贼三尸； 守城沐浴，则保固胎婴元神。 是柔和之心，为炼丹养道之要。 况天之生人，予人以生、无不予以仁慈，能克念归仁，长生永命之丹，即在是矣。 第六十八章 不争之德 善为士者不武，善战者不怒，善胜敌者不争，善用人者为之下。 是谓不争之德，是谓用人之力，是谓配天，古之极。 士，士师也。 士师用兵，原是尚武。 《易》曰：“刚中而应，行险而顺，神武而不杀。 ”是用武而不武，士之善为士者。 及大敌交锋，两军对垒，不得不陈师鞠旅，称干比戈，势奔山河，声震雷电。 然究其心，士卒无多，而强敌忽然压境，不难弹琴退中原之寇，和曲解敌国之围。 所谓不怒而成铁钺者是。 迨至班师振旅，奏凯言旋，人皆盈廷奏绩，而彼独逊谢不前——所谓大树将军者，可以无愧矣。 即或上赏频加，而反穷常觉赧颜——此善胜敌者所由不争也。 《书》曰：“汝惟不争，天下莫与汝争能”，其斯之谓欤？ 若此者，皆由推陈布公，集思广益，不自恃其才，善用众人之才以为才； 不自矜其智，善用众人之智以为智。 所谓卑以下人者，此也。 倘非察纳雅言，咨诹善道，虚怀若谷，谦尊而光。 乌有此善战善胜之能王天下犹反掌耶？ 是皆无争之德，有以服民也。 是皆用人之力有以威天下也。 是皆下顺民心，上合天道，有以服民心也。 是皆用人之力有以威天下也。 是皆下顺民心，上合天道，与天地参而立万古之人极也。 噫，非圣人至诚尽性，焉能于干戈扰攘之际，隐然寓太平揖让之风，用武不武，行怒不怒，相争不争如此乎？ 又况宽以御众，虑以下人，贤者在位，能者在职，天下之士，皆效忠抒悃，而愿赴功趋事，舍生奉命于其间如天道不言四时流行，万物献瑞，此所以配天地而立极也。 《诗》曰：“思文后稷，克配彼天，莫匪尔极。 ”微斯人其谁与归？ 此言药生进火，虽有猛烹急练功法，然亦因时为动，顺势而行，用武无武，所以无倾丹倒鼎之患也。 纵气机之动，真阳之生，至大至刚，充塞乎两大，何异战者之赫然震怒，所向披靡！ 况采取进火，只因其气之浩然者扩充之，非好为强也。 故一经洗练，而凡骨化为玉骨，凡身化作金身。 所谓取金丹于反掌，犹取天下如拾芥也。 惟其神凝无凝，息调无调，纯任乎天，不杂以人。 虽天人交争，理欲迭起，不得不存理以遏欲，尽人而合天。
chunks.translated_text:
The cultivation of the elixir—what else is it?
It is nothing but nurturing this compassion.

What is compassion?
When the King of Qi sees a cow trembling and cannot bear it,
When a villager sees a weak child fall into a well and feels distress—
These are the stirrings of the heart of virtue,
The return of the Heavenly heart.

Reflecting on this, such impulses and thoughts arise without ceasing—
Only fear that people fail to perceive them.

The scholar, from the spontaneous movement of true nature,
Expands and acts, thereby establishing a foundation for elixir cultivation.
Yet one must not seek breadth at the cost of neglect,
But rather adhere to restraint and subtlety.

With single-minded devotion, wholehearted sincerity—
The ancients said:
*"The heart must dwell within the chest,
Lest thoughts stray through the gate of totality."*

Thus, the more restrained, the broader;
The more subtle, the more manifest.
The more precise the restraint,
The wider the unfolding.

How can the scholar not take frugality as the root?
Though frugality is a virtue of the mind,
It is indeed a fine method to avoid excess through restraint.
Yet if not tempered with humility and gentleness,
One risks the violent nature igniting and harming the elixir.
Thus, restraint must be paired with utmost harmony—
In all things, humility and self-effacement,
Never presuming to lead—
This is the way of emptying oneself for others.

When the heart of virtue endures,
The Dao-qi endures as well.

If one values courage over compassion,
Seeks abundance over frugality,
And places oneself before others,
Then the heart is merely ordinary.
How could one expect to hold the Three Treasures without loss?

Moreover, when a person possesses compassion,
It is most effective in winning others’ favor—
In battle, victory is assured;
In defense, the city stands firm.
This is like tending the furnace with fire,
Burning away the Three Vermin;
Or guarding the city with ritual purity,
Thus preserving the embryo-spirit and original essence.

This gentle and harmonious heart
Is the key to elixir cultivation and Dao-nurturing.

Heaven, in creating man,
Endows him with life and, without fail, with compassion.
If one can constantly reflect and return to virtue,
The elixir of eternal life is already within reach.

**Chapter 68: The Virtue of Non-Contention**
A true warrior does not rely on brute force,
A skilled fighter does not rage,
One who triumphs over enemies does not contend,
And one who wields people places himself beneath them.

This is called the virtue of non-contention,
This is called harnessing others’ strength,
This is called aligning with Heaven—
The ultimate of the ancients.

*"Shì"* (士) means teacher of the people.
A teacher of the people wields armies,
Originally valuing martial prowess.
The *Yijing* says:
*"Firm yet yielding, advancing boldly yet following order,
Mighty yet without slaughter."*
This is wielding force without force—
The mark of a true teacher of the people.

When facing a great enemy, armies clash,
Two forces stand arrayed—
One cannot avoid deploying troops,
Brandishing weapons, charging like rivers,
Their roar shaking the heavens.

Yet in truth, with few soldiers,
A sudden onslaught by a mighty foe—
It is no difficulty to play music and drive back the invaders,
Or compose melodies to lift the siege.
This is the way of achieving might without anger.

When the troops return in triumph, proclaiming victory,
While others boast of their deeds,
He alone humbly withdraws—
Such a general can stand without shame.

Even if honors are heaped upon him,
He remains modest, his face flushed—
This is how one who conquers without contention behaves.

The *Shujing* says:
*"You alone do not contend,
And none in the world will contend with your ability."*
Is this not what is meant?

Such men arise from promoting the old while establishing the new,
Gathering wisdom and broadening benefits,
Not relying on their own talents,
But skillfully using others’ talents as their own;
Not boasting of their own wisdom,
But skillfully using others’ wisdom as their own.

This is the way of humbling oneself to elevate others—
If not for heeding wise counsel,
Consulting the good path,
Maintaining an open heart like a valley,
And practicing humble reverence—
How could one achieve such mastery of war and victory,
Turning the world as easily as flipping one’s palm?

This is the virtue of non-contention,
By which one serves the people.
This is harnessing others’ strength,
By which one commands the world.
This is aligning with the people below,
And harmonizing with Heaven above—
By which one serves the people’s hearts.
This is harnessing others’ strength,
By which one commands the world.
This is aligning with the people below,
And harmonizing with Heaven above—
Standing with Heaven and Earth,
And establishing the ultimate of all ages.

Alas! Without the saint’s utmost sincerity and fulfillment of nature,
How could one, amid the chaos of war,
Conceal the winds of peace and courtesy,
Wield force without force,
Act in anger without anger,
Contend without contention—
As described here?

Moreover, ruling with broad tolerance,
Planning with deference to others,
Placing the worthy in office,
And the capable in their posts—
Then all under Heaven’s scholars
Will offer loyalty and sincerity,
Eager to perform deeds and fulfill commands,
As if Heaven’s seasons flow without speech,
And all things present their offerings—
This is how one aligns with Heaven and Earth,
And establishes the ultimate.

The *Shijing* says:
*"Reflect on the virtuous Hou Ji,
Who aligned with Heaven—
None but you could achieve this ultimate."*
Without such a man, to whom shall we turn?

This speaks of refining the medicine with fire—
Though there are fierce methods of rapid distillation,
Yet one must act according to the time,
Follow the natural course,
Wield force without force—
Thus avoiding the peril of overturning the elixir or toppling the cauldron.

Even when the vital breath moves,
And true yang arises—
Most vast, most strong,
Filling the two great vessels—
What differs from a warrior’s fierce, overwhelming rage,
Sweeping all before him?

Moreover, when gathering and refining the fire,
It is only because the浩然 (*hàorán*) breath expands—
Not for the sake of strength itself.
Thus, after purification,
Ordinary bones become jade bones,
And the mortal body transforms into a golden body.

It is said: *"Taking the Golden Elixir in the palm,
Or seizing the world as one picks up a feather."*
Only when the spirit is both concentrated and effortless,
And breathing is both regulated and unrestrained,
Does one purely follow Heaven,
Without human interference.

Even when Heaven and man contend,
And reason and desire clash—
One must still uphold reason to restrain desire,
And exhaust human effort to merge with Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 迨至学粹功深，义精仁熟，毫无胜私克己、争功争能之心——仁者所以无敌于天下也。 若是者，皆由谦和柔顺，虚己下人，一听气机之动静，而与为转移。 故丹之成也，有不见而章，不动而变，无为而成者焉。 何殊善用人者为之下乎？ 修炼人道，果能在在安和，时时柔顺，欲不用遏而自遏，理不用存而自存，是谓不争之德也。 且以不争之心，顺理以施，随机而运，犹用人之力以成一己之功，是能范围天地之化而不过也。 孔子曰：“天何言哉，四时行焉，百物生焉。 ”圣人与道合真，正不啻天经地纬，而立万世之人极也。 第六十九章 哀者胜矣 用兵有言：“吾不敢为主而客，不敢进寸而退尺。 ”是谓行无行，攘无臂，仍无敌，执无兵。 祸莫大于轻敌，轻敌则几丧吾宝。 故抗兵相加，哀者胜矣。 古人用兵，着为战策，其有言曰：吾不敢为主而为客。 主犹君也，君主出令得专其政； 客犹臣也，臣主奉令一听之君，所谓“饶它为主我为宾”是。 是以吾为主，即以后天人心作主，而先天道心反退听焉。 吾岂敢以后天人心为主，而以后天人心为客，在在依之以为命也可。 不敢进寸而退尺者，盖谓战胜而进，即一寸也宜固守之； 如败而退，即跬步也不可让之。 若进有寸功，而退以尺计，是得少失多，难成易败。 在用兵，为不才之将； 在修道，为无功之人，吾岂敢哉？ 亦惟让彼为主，逊我为宾，则彼有可乘之机，我无可抵之隙，所谓制人而不为人所制，庶无挫辱之虞矣。 见可而进，知难而退。 其进也，必鼓其迈往之神； 其退也，不予以可攻之势。 如此小心，其难其慎，无非凡事让人以先，而己独处于后焉。 故其行军也，若人能行而己似不能行者然； 及其挺身而往，攘臂而前，又若人有臂而己无臂而己无臂者然。 迨至对垒交锋，两军相仍而战，又若人能敌而我无能敌者然。 虽伐鼓渊渊，振旗填填。 彼有所执，我岂独无兵者焉。 如此进不轻进，退不轻退，诚知社稷存亡，国家成败，系于一战，敌其可轻视乎哉？ 试观古来慎敌者往往成功； 轻敌者常常败绩。 如管子之伐山戎，子玉之战城濮可见矣。 况朝廷之兴衰，视将帅之得失。 如不临事审慎，逞其才、恃其智，而谓人莫己若，似孟明之超乘以过，高固之出贾余勇，未有不败国家亡家、覆宗灭祀者。 圣人之大宝曰信，轻敌者必丧人君之信。 惟两敌相抗，两兵相加，而自弱自柔，至慈至惠。 常以杀伐之气有于天地之和为忧； 不以兵革之威得辟土地之利为乐。 有时用兵疆场，亦出于万不得已。 虽未哭泣徇师，而仁慈恻怛心之心，哀痛迫切之情，早已流灵于陈师鞠旅之间，而三军共沐其生成，万姓咸相为感激也。 所以君子有不战，战必胜矣。 非哀痛之心有以及人身，而入人心也哉？ 此喻真阳发生，气机充壮，方可进火行工。 如不静候铅气之气，而慢以神升降进退，循环运转，未有不邪火焚身，大遭困辱者。 当其四候之际，必候坎气之自动，而离不得以专主，故曰“吾不敢为主而为客”。 修炼之道，进行则常，退后则灾。 如天之运行不息，水之流行不停，始克蒸蒸日上。 若时作时辍，一暴十寒，则是进寸而退尺，功少而过多，终身必无成功矣。 若此者，由不知归根复命之道乃日用常行之道，不可以智计取，不可以作为得；
chunks.translated_text:
When cultivation reaches its utmost refinement—
Principles profound, benevolence mature—
No trace remains of selfish ambition,
No striving for merit or prowess—
Thus the benevolent stand unmatched beneath Heaven.

Such is the way of humility and yielding,
Of emptiness and submission to others,
Of attuning to the ebb and flow of *qi*,
And letting it guide one’s transformation.

Therefore, the elixir’s completion
Has its unseen yet manifest,
Its motionless yet ever-changing,
Its effortless yet inevitable fulfillment.
What differs from a master’s skill in wielding others?

In cultivating the human *Dao*,
If one remains ever at peace,
Ever yielding and compliant,
Desire needing no suppression to suppress itself,
Reason needing no invocation to arise naturally—
This is called the *virtue* of non-contention.

With a heart of non-contention,
Following principle in action,
Adapting to circumstances in movement—
It is as though using others’ strength
To achieve one’s own success,
Yet encompassing Heaven and Earth’s transformations
Without overreaching.

Confucius said:
*"What does Heaven speak?
The four seasons proceed therein,
All things take life therein."*

The Sage merges with the *Dao* in truth,
Standing firm as the very threads of Heaven and Earth,
And establishing the ultimate measure for all ages.

**Chapter 69: The Victorious Through Compassion**
In warfare, it is said:
*"I dare not be the aggressor while the other defends,
Nor advance an inch only to retreat a foot."*
This is called:
Moving without movement,
Pushing without arms,
Conquering without force,
Seizing without weapons.

No greater calamity than underestimating the enemy—
Underestimating the enemy risks losing what is most precious.

Thus, when armies clash,
The compassionate prevail.

Ancient strategists spoke of battle tactics:
*"I dare not be the aggressor while the other defends."*
The aggressor is like a sovereign—
A sovereign’s decrees command absolute authority;
The defender is like a minister—
A minister obeys the sovereign’s will,
As in *"Let the other be the host, I the guest."*

Thus, if I am the aggressor,
It means my post-Heavenly human-heart takes command,
While my pre-Heavenly *Dao*-heart retreats in submission.
How dare I let the post-Heavenly human-heart dominate,
And treat it as the guest while relying on it utterly?

*"I dare not advance an inch only to retreat a foot"*—
This means:
When victorious, even an inch gained must be firmly held;
When defeated, not even a single step may be conceded.
If one advances with an inch’s gain
Yet retreats by a foot’s measure,
It is to gain little and lose much,
Difficult to succeed and easy to fail.

In warfare, this is the mark of an incompetent general;
In cultivating the *Dao*, this is the fate of one who achieves nothing.
How dare I?

Only by yielding to the other as host,
And submitting myself as guest,
Does the enemy have no advantage to exploit,
And I no vulnerability to attack—
Thus, controlling others without being controlled,
Avoiding humiliation entirely.

Advance where opportunity allows,
Retreat where difficulty arises.
In advancing, one must rouse the spirit of boundless momentum;
In retreating, one must not present an assailable posture.
Such caution, such vigilance—
Always yielding precedence to others,
While placing oneself last.

Thus, in marching armies,
It appears as though others can move while I seem unable;
Yet when I press forward with resolve,
Stretching forth my arms,
It seems as though others have arms while I have none.
When facing the enemy in battle,
With armies locked in struggle,
It seems as though others can resist while I cannot.

Though drums thunder and flags billow,
The enemy wields weapons—
How could I alone be weaponless?

Thus, advancing without recklessness,
Retreating without haste—
Truly knowing that the fate of the state,
The rise or fall of the nation,
Hangs upon this single battle—
How could the enemy be treated lightly?

Observe the ancients who treated the enemy with caution—
They often succeeded;
Those who underestimated the enemy—
They invariably failed.
As seen in Guan Zi’s campaign against the Yanrong,
Or Zi Yu’s battle at Chengpu.

Moreover, the prosperity or decline of the court
Depends on the success or failure of its generals.
If one does not approach matters with utmost prudence,
Boasting of talent or relying on cunning,
And claiming none can surpass them—
Like Meng Ming’s reckless advance,
Or Gao Gu’s overconfident charge—
There has never been one who did not bring ruin to the state,
Destruction to the family,
And extinction to the ancestral line.

The Sage’s greatest treasure is *trust*—
Underestimating the enemy betrays the sovereign’s faith.

When two armies confront,
Two forces clash—
Yet one remains weak and yielding,
Most compassionate, most benevolent.
Always fearing that the *qi* of slaughter
Disrupts the harmony of Heaven and Earth;
Never rejoicing in the might of arms
To expand territory through conquest.

Warfare on the battlefield
Is but a last resort.
Though no weeping follows the army’s retreat,
The heart of compassion and pity,
The anguish and urgency of grief,
Already permeate the encamped troops,
And the three armies are nourished by it,
While the common people respond with gratitude.

Thus, the virtuous either do not war,
Or, if they do, they prevail.
Is this not because the heart of compassion
Extends to others,
And enters their very souls?

This illustrates the birth of true *yang*,
The flourishing of *qi*—
Only then may the fire be refined and the work proceed.

If one does not quietly await the *yin* essence’s movement,
And leisurely regulates the ascent and descent,
The advance and retreat,
The cyclical circulation of spirit—
There will be none who do not suffer from errant fire,
And face great humiliation.

At the four critical junctures,
One must await the *kan* *qi*’s spontaneous motion,
Lest *li* presume to dominate.
Thus it is said:
*"I dare not be the aggressor while the other defends."*

In the *Dao* of cultivation,
Advancing brings stability,
Retreating brings disaster.
Like Heaven’s ceaseless motion,
Like water’s unending flow—
Only then does one ascend daily without halt.
If one proceeds intermittently,
Now pushing, now neglecting—
One step forward, ten steps back—
Gaining little, losing much—
Success will never be attained in a lifetime.

This arises from ignorance of the *Dao* of returning to the root,
Of restoring one’s true nature—
A path of daily practice,
Not to be seized by clever schemes,
Nor achieved through contrived actions.

chunks.original_text: 惟逆修丹道，顺运自然，学如不学，功而无功，相因而造，顺势而前，无少阻滞，无一把持，若禹之治水，行所无事而已。 倘进火行符，轻于进退，犹行兵者之轻视敌人，未有不火起伤丹，炉残鼎败，以致铅汞一齐飞散者。 噫，纯任自然，敬慎不败，固缉熙于光明； 若妄作聪明，长生之宝必因此后天尸贼，为之戕害无存，又安望其成丹而可大可久哉？ 惟仁慈一片，哀痛十分，而后出之以和平，行之以柔顺，自然所向披靡，战无不胜。 学人慎勿以后天识神为主，而先天元气皆退听焉，庶几其不差矣。 第七十章 被褐怀玉 吾言甚易知，甚易行。 天下莫能知，莫能行。 言有宗，事有君。 夫惟无知，是以不我知。 知我者希，则我贵矣。 是以圣人被揭怀玉。 大道者，人心固有之良，日用常行之事，至近至约，不可顺臾离也。 离则无道，无道则无人，又何言之有？ 况吾之所言，虽累于累万，盈箧盈箱，不可胜数，要皆切于人心，近于日用，无有难知难行者。 顾何天下莫能知莫能行者？ 岂吾言之不易知不易行乎？ 盖言有宗也，即人所不学而知之良知也； 事有君也，即人所不学而能之良能也。 惟言知有宗，则近取诸身，而言皆善言； 事知有君，则默窥其隐，而行皆善行。 夫道若大路然，岂难知难行者哉？ 反身而诚，乐莫大焉。 若不知言之有宗，事之有君，而求诸高远之地，广博之乡，是以玩物丧志，务广而荒，以为形役，性为气累，而本来天德之良，迷慨欤？ 虽然，其知也于我何加？ 其不知也于我何损？ 况我之所以为我，初不因人之知不知也。 知我者希，则我之贵乎我者仍自若也。 是以圣人被至贱之褐，内怀至贵之玉，晦迹山林，藏身岩穴，亦惟顺性命之理，参天地之道，以修其在己，而人之知否从违，概不问焉。 此所以圣者益圣，而愚者愈愚矣。 太上之言，头头是道，字字切身。 即人以言道，即道以言身，易莫易于此矣。 夫何难知难行者哉？ 顾人之昧昧者，良由道在迩而求诸远，事在易而求诸难。 不务真常大道，反求糟粕绪余。 如辞章记诵刑名术数之类，学愈博而心愈荒，事愈繁而性愈劣，无怪乎太上道言。 当时为人心所同，后世为太上所独也。 良由不明言之有宗，事之有君耳。 夫宗者君者，即人身之“中”也。 尧舜授受心传，无非“允执厥中”而已。 后如文之“纯一”，参之"慎独"，柯之“良知”，莫非人身之一“中”也。 此个“中”字，所包甚广。 其在人身，一在守有形之“中”——朱子云：“守中制外”。 夫守中者，回光返照，注意规中。 于脐下一寸三分处，不即不离是。 一在守无形之中——《中庸》云：“喜怒哀乐未发谓之中。 ”罗从彦教李延平：“静中观喜怒哀乐未发气象，此未发时不闻不睹，戒慎恐惧，自然性定神清，方见本来面目。 然后人欲易净，天理复明。 自古圣贤仙佛，皆以此为第一步工夫。 但始须守乎勉然之中，终则纯乎自然之中。 ”三圣人名目各有不同，总不外地“中”字为之宗，为之君。 即如吾教以凝神调息为主，然后回观本窍，心无其心，气无其气，乃得心平气和。 心平则神始凝，气和则息始调。 其要只在心平二字。 心不起波谓之平，能执其中谓之平； 平即在此中也。
